title: Meeting with Liaison Magistrates and Contact Points
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 03 October 2007 On Tuesday 2 October, Eurojust organised a meeting with 24 Liaison Magistrates and ‘Contact Points’ from all over Europe and beyond. Eurojust has close links with these Liaison Magistrates and Contact Points, located all over the world. With them, practical and case-related information can be shared regarding the right way to co-operate with the different jurisdictions and to address the appropriate persons and authorities.   This meeting was to follow up previous encounters of 2002, 2004 and 2005 in Brussels and The Hague. The aim of the meeting was to share the invaluable experience in co-operation at the bilateral level and the Eurojust experience at the multilateral level, especially since the EU’s Enlargements of May 2004 and January 2007. A special focus was given on the assessment of the respective roles and strategies with reference to practical case work examples and how Eurojust might best interact in order to optimise the support for national authorities in co-coordinating the fight against international organised and serious crime. Liaison Magistrates were present from Croatia, Estonia, Finland, France, Morocco, Netherlands, Pakistan, Poland, Spain, United Kingdom and the USA. Contact Points came from Albania, Bosnia Herzegovina, Croatia, the Former Yugoslavian Republic of Macedonia, Iceland, Israel, Japan, Liechtenstein, Mongolia, Republic of Montenegro, Norway, Sweden and Ukraine. At the end of the meeting, Ms Michèle Coninsx, National Member for Belgium who chaired the meeting, concluded: “This was a very useful working meeting, in which we gained more insight in tasks, experience and expertise, from colleagues and practitioners all over the world. Especially in the field of drug trafficking and terrorism these professional contacts may be very beneficial. In this perspective a clear status at EU level for the LM could be an advantage for them in the future. Additionally, we were pleased to be able to inform our visitors about recent developments within Eurojust.” For more information, please contact: Mr Joannes THUY, Press Officer & SpokespersonEUROJUST, Maanweg 174, 2516 AB, The Hague, The NetherlandsTel +31 70 412 5508 - Fax +31 70 412 5005E-mail: jthuy[AT]eurojust.europa.eu

title: Co-ordination meeting on drug trafficking in the Balkans
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 19 Sep 2007 Eurojust organised in Tirana, Albania, the first co-ordination meeting on drug trafficking in the Balkans, involving Albania, Bulgaria, Italy and Slovenia. The meeting, concerning drug trafficking in the Balkans, was held in Tirana, Albania, on 17 and 18 September. It was the first co-ordination meeting of its kind held in Tirana, Albania, organised by Eurojust. The meeting was attended by representatives of judicial and law enforcement authorities from Albania, Bulgaria, Italy and Slovenia. In total, 35 prosecutors and high-level police officers participated in the meeting. Also in attendance was a representative of the Direzione Nazionale Antimafia. Co-operation with Albanian authorities is essential for combating organised crime in the Balkans. As a result of the meeting, Eurojust will develop further co-operation to combat organised crime in the region. Only a shared commitment by all the involved national authorities will lead to a general overview of this trans-national criminal phenomenon. The purpose of the meeting was to gain a wider perspective on how the illegal trafficking is organised, and to verify and establish connections among the national investigations to establish a common investigative strategy for the future. After the meeting, on behalf of Eurojust’s National Members for Bulgaria, Italy and Slovenia, Ms Carmen Manfredda (Deputy National Member for Italy) commented: “We achieved our goals. We discussed the case in which these countries are involved. On the basis of this discussion we developed further co-operation in combating organised crime in the region, in accordance with the expectations expressed by Ministers of Justice from Portugal, Germany, France, Italy and Slovenia in a joint article published in newspapers earlier this week.I would like to thank the Albanian authorities, in particular the Director of the Foreign Relations Department, Mr Ardian Visha, for the hospitality offered to Eurojust and the participants. I am sure that this meeting will be the first step for improving a useful co-operation between our countries.”

title: New Vice-President of the College
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 12 December 2007 During the plenary meeting of the College of Eurojust on 11 December 2007, Ms Michèle Coninsx was elected as Vice-President to replace Mr José Luis Lopes da Mota, who was elected President of the College in November 2007. Mr Lopes da Mota, President of the College of Eurojust, commented: “I am very pleased that my colleague and friend Ms Coninsx has been elected Vice-President of the College of Eurojust today. Ms Coninsx joined Eurojust on 1 March 2001, at the time still ‘Pro-Eurojust’ in Brussels, and was President of Pro-Eurojust during the Belgian Presidency, July-December 2001.As the National Member for Belgium, she soon became Chair of the College Anti-Terrorism Team. Michèle’s previous experience as a prosecutor means she will be a great asset to the Presidency Team. Her election will enable Michèle to further develop her excellent career at a higher level as Vice-President of the College”. Together with President José Luís Lopes da Mota and Vice-President Raivo Sepp, Ms Coninsx will represent the College, substitute for the President in his absence, assist with management of the College and monitor the daily work of Eurojust’s Administrative Director. In accordance with Article 28(2) of the Eurojust Decision, the results of the election must be approved by the Secretary General of the European Council, Mr Javier Solana. Michèle Coninsx is National Member for Belgium. She has more than 15 years' experience as a prosecutor. She worked for nine years for the International Civil Aviation Organisation and was responsible for anti-terrorism relating to aircraft sabotage and hijacking. Before joining Eurojust she was a National Prosecutor in Belgium dealing with terrorism and organised crime. Michèle Coninsx (Hi-res photo available at the Press Office)

title: EUROJUST and CROATIA signed Judicial Co-operation Agreement
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 19 November 2007 On Friday, 9 November, the President of the College of Eurojust, Michael Kennedy, and the Minister of Justice of Croatia, Ms Ana Lovrin, signed an official agreement on strengthening judicial co-operation between Eurojust and Croatia. The ceremony, held in the margins of the JHA Council meeting in Brussels, was attended by Vice-President Franco Frattini and Alberto Costa, Minister of Justice of Portugal and President of the European Council. The purpose of this agreement is to formalise and develop closer co-operation between Croatia and Eurojust, in order to increase the effectiveness of their response to combating serious forms of international, cross-border and organised crime. This will be the fifth co-operation agreement concluded between Eurojust and non-European Union countries. The previous agreements were signed during 2005 and 2006 between Eurojust and Norway, Iceland, Romania and the USA. At the ceremony, Mr. Lopes da Mota, newly elected President of the College of Eurojust, confirmed the added value of this agreement: “I am delighted that Eurojust has been able to conclude this agreement with Croatia, an important partner. This agreement will provide a platform for improved co-operation and co-ordination of investigations and prosecutions involving the national authorities of Croatia and Eurojust. The agreement is particularly important because of the neighbour policy of the European Union and Croatia is a candidate country. With this close co-operation agreement, Croatia will be fully involved in the common efforts of Eurojust and the Member States in the fight against all types of serious organised and cross-border crime.”

title: Raivo Sepp is new Vice-President
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 13 September 2007 Raivo Sepp, Eurojust’s National Member for Estonia,was elected as new Vice-President. During the plenary meeting of the College of Eurojust on 13 September 2007, Mr Raivo Sepp was elected as Vice-President to replace Mr Roelof Jan Manschot, who will retire in October. Mr Kennedy, President of the College of Eurojust commented: “I am delighted that my colleague Mr Raivo Sepp has been elected Vice-President of the College of Eurojust. Mr Sepp joined Eurojust in May 2004 as the Estonian National Member. He soon became chairman of the Casework Strategy and Performance Management Team. It is a sign of the maturity of our young organisation that a National Member from a new Member State has to be elected as Vice-President. Raivo's previous experience as Prosecutor General of Estonia means he will be a great asset for the Presidency Team. His election will enable Raivo to develop his excellent commitment at a higher level as Vice-President of the College”. Together with Michael Kennedy and Vice-President José Luis Lopes da Mota, Vice-President Raivo Sepp will represent the College, substitute for the President in his absence and assist with management of the College and monitor the daily work of Eurojust’s Administrative Director. In accordance with Article 28(2) of the Eurojust Decision, the results of the election must be approved by the Secretary General of the European Council, Mr Javier Solana. Raivo Sepp is National Member for Estonia. He joined Eurojust in May 2004. He has 18 years' experience in the judiciary. He started his career in the prosecution service as an investigator. He has also worked as the Director of the Pre-trial Investigation Bureau. Later, he was the County Police Chief and the Deputy Director General of the Police Board. He served for five years as the Prosecutor General of the Republic. Raivo Sepp (Hi-res photo available at the Press Office)

title: Raivo Sepp is new Vice-President [et]
text: Page Content14-09-2007 Riigiprokurör Raivo Sepp valiti Eurojusti asepresidendiks Eile, 13. septembril valiti Eesti esindaja Eurojusti juures riigiprokurör Raivo Sepp Eurojusti asepresidendiks. Seega on Eesti esimene uutest Euroopa Liidu liikmesriikidest, kelle liige Eurojusti nii kõrgele ametikohale on valitud. Riigi peaprokurör Norman Aas ütles, et Raivo Sepa valimine Eurojusti asepresidendiks on tunnustus kogu Eesti prokuratuurile. „See näitab, et me oleme rahvusvaheliselt arvestatav partner kuritegevuse vastases võitluses.“ Eurojust on justiitskoostöö võrgustik, mis aitab Euroopa Liidu liikmesriike erinevate raskete kuritegude menetlemisel, sealhulgas terrorismi, pettuste ning inim– ja narkokaubanduse valdkonnas. Eurojusti töö eesmärk on parandada liikmesriikide õigusasutuste vahelist koostööd ja koordineerida eeluurimise ja isikute kohtu alla andmise protsessi. Eurojusti presidendiks on Ühendkuningriikide liige Michael Kennedy ja teiseks asepresidendiks Portugali liige Jose–Luis Lopes da Mota. Riigiprokurör Raivo Sepp on Eesti esindaja Eurojusti juures alates 2004. aastast. Ta on selle aja jooksul aidanud Eesti õiguskaitseorganeid paljude erinevate piiriüleste kuritegude menetlemisel. Lisaks sellele aitab Raivo Sepp Eurojusti arengule kaasa juhtides kahte alalist töögruppi – Eurojusti administreerimise ja Eurojusti arengu töögruppi. Raivo Sepp

title: Secure Communication link Eurojust - Europol
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 07 June 2007 Secure communication link between Eurojust and Europolfacilitates the combating of cross-border crime in the EU In the presence of Vice-President of the European Commission Franco Frattini a Memorandum of Understanding was signed today by Mr Michael Kennedy, President of the College of Eurojust, and Mr Max-Peter Ratzel, Director of Europol. The agreement regulates the establishment, implementation and operation of a secure communication link for the transmission of information between Eurojust and Europol. "I warmly welcome this new secure communication link between two of the key actors in the EU architecture for internal security”, said Vice-President Franco Frattini, Commissioner for Freedom, Security and Justice, adding that: "This new tool symbolises the enhanced co-operation between Europol and Eurojust in the fight against serious cross-border crime and the support provided to national law enforcement and prosecuting authorities, from which EU citizens can only benefit. Combined with the protocols to the Europol Convention, including Joint Investigation Teams, access to the Analytical Work Files of Europol, etc., and with the expected effects of the future Council Decision replacing the Europol Convention, this new secure communication link constitutes another step towards the realisation of an area of freedom, security and justice in Europe.” “I am delighted that the secure network line between Eurojust and Europol is now in place”, President Kennedy of Eurojust noted. “In the future it will allow both organisations to exchange highly confidential information quickly and easily. It is a vital step forward in our joint fight against organised serious cross-border crime in the EU and beyond. The establishment of our secure communication link to Europol was a key priority to ensure we maximise the effectiveness of our co-operation with Europol. Amongst other things it will enable Eurojust to improve its capacity to obtain information and better operational co-operation in Europol’s Analytical Work Files. It will also help to develop the project on Joint Investigation Teams more efficiently and, most importantly, to be more involved in the preparation for and contribution to the Organised Crime Threat Assessment. Our relationship with Europol is good but we must look at areas where it can be further improved”. "During the past year”, Director Ratzel of Europol stated, "great efforts have been made by Europol and Eurojust to solve the formal problems encountered in obtaining and sharing information from Europol’s Analytical Work Files. The so-called Danish protocols came into effect recently allowing Eurojust to be a member of Europol’s Analytical Work Files. Analysts at Europol have also started co-operating regularly with analysts at Eurojust in casework-connected topics such as terrorism, drug trafficking, trafficking in human beings and serious fraud. Today an electronic navel-string between Eurojust and Europol is established, and this is an example of how we live up to the principle of availability called for by the politicians. In other words, the secure communication link will make it easier and faster for our staff to retrieve information and by this we can serve our partners in the Member States even better”. Background This secure communication link is a follow-up to the agreement concluded between Eurojust and Europol on 9 June 2004. To realise the co-operation agreement with respect to the exchange of information, it was decided to establish a secure communication link between both organisations to allow for the electronic transmission of information. Consultations on all levels took place between Eurojust and Europol. Based on the requirements, a technical solution was developed in co-operation between the two organisations. This secure communication link is in fact the extension of Eurojust’s internal secure network to Europol’s premises, making use of stand-alone workstations. There is no interconnection between this secure network and any other network or system. The management and handling of information in general, transmitted via the secure communication link, is governed by the co-operation agreement and the legal framework of Europol and Eurojust. Information sent and received via the secure communication link will be subject to the confidentiality and security standards of each organisation in accordance with Article 13 of the co-operation agreement. Following the signing ceremony, the link was activated. title: Eurojust implements a videoconference system to improve co-ordination meetings
text: Page ContentThe Hague , 11 May 2007 Last week, a co-ordination meeting was held at Eurojust using videoconference technology, allowing participants from distant countries to easily participate in the discussions and exchange of information. This was the first time that such a system was used during a co-ordination meeting. The co-ordination meeting, urgently requested by the Italian judicial authorities, involving European countries and two Third States, was not only meant to improve international co-operation, but also to exchange information and to offer data essential to the dismantling of a dangerous network dealing with appalling crimes, such as child pornography and sexual abuse of minors. The outcome of this event was very important for Eurojust’s operational work, as it helped to establish links between judicial authorities and police bodies all over the world. Mrs Carmen Manfredda, Deputy National Member for Italy, who chaired the meeting, commented afterwards: “Last week we really fulfilled the essence of our activity and achieved the aim for which Eurojust was created. The meeting was not organised in the interest of single countries, but in the general interest of justice. This videoconference has turned out to be a potential tool to defeat organised crime. Nowadays criminals take advantage of the most recent technological systems, such as the internet, data encryption in real time exchange, satellite communication, mobile devices, etc. to carry out their illegal activities. In order to stop all this, it is important that we adjust our resources to a more and more high-tech society.” The high-level outcome of the videoconference has been greatly appreciated by all external participants, especially the requesting Italian authorities.

title: Eurojust and Europol co-ordinated action against organised criminal network in six countries
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 13 June 2007 Eurojust and Europol co-ordinated action against organised criminal network in six countries This morning, a large Europe-wide co-ordinated police and judicial action took place in Belgium, Germany, France, the Netherlands, Italy and the United Kingdom. In all these countries, house searches and arrests were made, based on European Arrest Warrants issued by the investigating magistrate in Liege, Belgium. The targets are members of a transnational Albanian criminal network, who were also operating in Luxembourg and Austria. The criminal organisation was involved in trafficking of drugs, trafficking in human beings and prostitution, money laundering, trafficking of illegal arms, trafficking in stolen vehicles, document fraud and organised transnational burglary.  The extensive investigation started in July 2006, following the arrest of a drugs courier in France, transporting cocaine to Italy. Following co-ordination meetings at Eurojust in 2006 and 2007, a co-ordinated and coherent approach to the police investigations and prosecutions was possible, leading to successful actions and positive results. Eurojust and Europol will continue to support national authorities in their fight against criminal networks by following this strategy. Mr Max-Peter Ratzel, Director of Europol, commented: “I congratulate the Belgian authorities on this successful result. The operation is an excellent and valuable example of what law enforcement authorities can achieve via joint efforts and co-operation.”Mr Michael Kennedy, President of the College of Eurojust added: “To be effective in the fight against organised cross-border crime in Europe investigators and prosecutors must co-ordinate their activity and work closely together. I am pleased that Eurojust, which was created specifically to assist and support these types of cases, has played a significant role in the successful actions that have taken place today in six European Union Member States.” Some results of the actions In Belgium, around 200 policemen came into action in Liege, Huy, Arlon, Tongeren and Antwerp; 40 house searches were made and 40 persons questioned. Sixteen people were brought to the investigating magistrate and four arrested so far. A large sum of money, weapons, 5 kg of cannabis, false documents, computers and cars were seized in Belgium Additional information will be issued in due time by the national authorities.

title: Eurojust held co-ordination meeting on JAS Gripen jetfighters case
text: Page ContentThe Hague , 10 May 2007 A co-ordination meeting was held at Eurojust regarding allegations of corruption in relation to purchase and lease of JAS Gripen jetfighters on 10 May 2007. An exchange of information took place at the meeting between Sweden, United Kingdom, Czech Republic, Switzerland and Austria in order to co-ordinate further investigation.

title: Eurojust held co-ordination meeting on tackling Europe-based drug labs
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 05 July 2007 Eurojust organised a co-ordination meeting involving three countries in the fight against a new phenomenon in Europe. Initiated by the Greek National Member at Eurojust, a co-ordination meeting was held at Eurojust on a new phenomenon in the European Union. Eurojust received information from the Special Investigation Service on Drug Trafficking in Greece of the discovery of a laboratory in Athens producing cocaine, with links to the United Kingdom and the Netherlands. The mastermind of the criminal organisation is a UK citizen. The co-ordination meeting involved investigators and experts from Greece, the UK and the Netherlands, supported by analysts and liaison officers from Europol. It was the first time that Eurojust and Europol joined forces in the fight against drug trafficking under the Eurojust-Europol co-operation agreement. During the meeting, information was exchanged and it was agreed that future actions will be co-ordinated. After the meeting, Mr Lampros Patsavellas, National Member for Greece, commented: “This meeting was very fruitful. Eurojust was pleased to host a meeting where all investigating parties were present. This was the first meeting of its kind. I am very happy to commence co-operation that will lead to the dismantling of Europe-based drug labs. We have observed a new course of action: criminal networks are now setting up drug labs in Europe. Dealers want to avoid controls by the naval and customs officials at sea while transporting the drugs. They also may have more profits this way. Europe must be prepared to confront this new trade. We will have to trace every drug lab in Europe.” Participants from Europol were also very pleased with this meeting. In the future, more meetings on this kind of case will be organised at Eurojust.

title: Eurojust held co-ordination meeting on JAS Gripen jetfighters case [cs]
text: Page ContentThe Hague , 10 May 2007 Dne 10.5. proběhla v Eurojust schůzka ve věci podezření z korupčního jednání v souvislosti s prodejem a pronájmem stíhaček JAS Gripen. Na schůzce proběhla výměna informací mezi Švédskem, Velkou Británií, Českou republikou, Švýcarskem a Rakouskem za účelem koordinace dalšího vyšetřování.

title: Internet network sale of fake pills dismantled
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 2 May 2007 Within the framework of a judicial investigation by the “Pôle santé du parquet de Paris”, the Public Health Department of the Public Prosecutor, and following international rogatory commissions by two investigating magistrates, four simultaneous police actions were performed on 24, 25 and 26 April 2007 in Sweden, Romania, the Netherlands and Denmark, all prepared and co-ordinated by Eurojust in The Hague. These actions have led to a series of searches in all four countries and two arrests in Sweden based on European Arrest Warrants. These co-ordinated actions finally resulted in the dismantling of a network of internet sales of counterfeit pills of the drug “Rimonabant”, designed and produced by the French group SANOFI-AVENTIS and recently put on the market in France as “Acomplia”. The judicial investigation in Paris unveiled an international traffic of pharmaceutical products, produced in unhygienic environments, then sold and consumed in amounts in violation of the regulations and without any medical control. The counterfeiting of such pills constitutes a serious fraud and an important health risks as they are made widely available via the internet to all consumers, including minors. This type of criminality on the internet, by definition abstract, anonymous, without borders and transitory, requires an adapted judicial response to be modulated to the level and methods used on the internet. Meetings which took place at Eurojust in The Hague among the different judicial authorities and police officers from the five countries involved have shown an exceptional high-level co-operation. The flexible and efficient European co-operation among the judicial and police authorities in the fight against this type of fraud has been beneficial to the European citizens. The execution of four synchronized rogatory commissions in four countries required on the spot involvement of eleven French investigators of the Central Brigade for Industrial and Artistic Fraud (BCRCIA) and The Central Office for the Fight Against Crimes using Technology and Communication (OCLCLTIC). They assisted in the judicial operations performed in Denmark, United Kingdom, the Netherlands and Sweden, a large police force operating in each country. For the first time, the efficiency of an international co-operation in the domain of fraud on drugs, showed the need to build and further establish a European judicial area opening the path to other investigations. For the countries concerned, the concrete response of a joint judicial and operational approach resulted in a big success on European co-operation, both in the fight against cyber crime and in the area of public health. The success of these operations is mainly due to the high-level of co-operation and professional support by Eurojust, contributing to the smooth preparation of the actions and the synergy between European police officers and magistrates who were from the beginning of their investigations confronted with the need to work in close co-operation while respecting their respective national judicial systems.

title: Ernst Merz is new Administrative Director for Eurojust
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 25 July 2007 Eurojust is pleased to report that on 24 July 2007 the College decided to offer Mr Ernst Merz a five year contract as Administrative Director for Eurojust from the beginning of September 2007. As the Administrative Director’s current contract was due to terminate in September 2007, the College had decided earlier in the year that there should be an open competition and that the post should be advertised to attract the best candidates for the future development of Eurojust.  The post was advertised with a closing date of 20 June 2007. There were a range of applicants. A Selection Board, appointed by the College, including an outside specialist-expert in recruitment, and observers from the Commission and the Council Secretariat, interviewed four candidates. Two candidates were deemed suitable for the post and were presented to the College. After long and careful deliberation, the College decided to offer a further five-year contract to the current Administrative Director, Mr Ernst Merz. The College also agreed to make some changes in the working relationship between the College and the Administrative Director, to further improve the efficient operational challenges that face a new and developing organisation. The President of the College, Mr Kennedy commented: “I am delighted that the period of uncertainty for both Eurojust and also for Mr Merz has now been resolved. We have achieved a great deal during the past five years, and there has been good leadership of the Eurojust Administration, but Eurojust is now a very different organisation which needs to develop in different ways. This calls for a change in focus to ensure that we get the best from the skills and abilities of the College, but also from the skills and talents of all Administrative staff. We must work more effectively and more efficiently and better as a team to deliver the services expected by the investigators and prosecutors and all the citizens of Europe. Together we must do our utmost to success in the fight against organised crime.” The College offered its congratulations to Mr Merz and all staff members at Eurojust joined in offering Mr Merz similar congratulations. Mr Merz commented:  “I am pleased and honoured that the College has decided to reappoint me as Eurojust’s Administrative Director. This gives me the opportunity to contribute to the future of Eurojust and also to the European Judicial Network (EJN). I will assess what went well and what needs improvement, and submit proposals to the College to take the necessary decisions and actions. I will make the decisions when they fall in the remit of my competence. A leader is only as strong as the team that supports him or her. I believe that the success of Eurojust has been, in a considerable part, due to the support of a motivated and professional staff. I look forward to a continued productive co-operation with every one working for Eurojust, National Members, Deputies, Assistants and administrative and supporting staff.”

title: Internet network sale of fake pills dismantled
text: Page ContentLa Haye, 2 Mai 2007 Dans le cadre d’une information judiciaire ouverte par le Pôle santé du parquet de Paris et sur commissions rogatoires internationales de deux magistrats instructeurs du Pôle santé publique de Paris, ont été menées les 24, 25 et 26 avril 2007 en SUEDE, au ROYAUME UNI, aux PAYS BAS et au DANEMARK quatre opérations de police préparées et coordonnées avec le soutien d’EUROJUST à La Haye. Donnant lieu à une série de perquisitions et auditions dans l’ensemble de ces pays et à deux arrestations suivies de deux mandats d’arrêt européens en cours d’exécution en Suède, ces opérations simultanées ont contribué au démantèlement d’un trafic internet de vente de contrefaçons d’une molécule pharmaceutique dénommée Rimonabant, mise au point et brevetée par le groupe français SANOFI-AVENTIS et récemment commercialisée en France sous la marque Acomplia. L’information judiciaire en cours à Paris porte sur un trafic international de produits fabriqués et conditionnés dans des conditions d’hygiène indéterminées, puis vendus et consommés dans des dosages non conformes, hors de tout contrôle médical. Ces contrefaçons de médicaments constituent une tromperie comportant des risques non négligeables pour la santé et d’autant plus préjudiciable que les produits sont facilement accessibles de n’importe quel consommateur, majeur ou mineur, en tous points d’accessibilité internet. Ce type de criminalité sur internet par définition abstraite, anonyme, sans frontières et à localisation éphémère  nécessite d’adapter la réponse judiciaire en modulant les méthodes et  l’échelle des enquêtes. Réunies à La Haye sous l’égide d’Eurojust, les différentes autorités judiciaires et policières des cinq pays concernés ont prouvé par une collaboration d’exceptionnelle qualité,  la mobilisation et l’efficacité de la coopération européenne, tant judiciaire que policière, dans la lutte contre ce type de fraude préjudiciable à l’ensemble de la communauté européenne, voire à  la communauté internationale. L’exécution de ces quatre commissions rogatoires synchronisées dans quatre pays européens a nécessité le déplacement de onze enquêteurs français de la Brigade Centrale pour la Répression des Contrefaçons Industrielles et Artistiques ( BCRCIA) et de l’Office Central de Lutte contre la Criminalité Liée aux Technologies de l’Information et de la Communication ( OCLCLTIC) assistant aux opérations menées par les autorités danoises, britanniques, néerlandaises et suédoises, chacun de ces Etats mobilisant également un important effectif policier. L’efficacité de ces opérations suscitant pour la première fois la coopération internationale dans le domaine de la contrefaçon de médicaments, contribue à construire et à consolider l’espace judiciaire européen en ouvrant la voie d’autres enquêtes. Pour les Etats  concernés, l’émergence concrète d’une réaction judiciaire commune et opérationnelle constitue un incontestable succès de coopération européenne, à la fois dans la lutte contre la cybercriminalité et dans le domaine des infractions à la santé publique. Ce succès a reposé dans  une large mesure sur l’exceptionnelle qualité du soutien d’Eurojust, contribuant à la fluidité des opérations et à la synergie des magistrats et policiers européens, désormais confrontés dès le début de leurs enquêtes à la nécessité de travailler en concordance et de conjuguer les particularités de leurs systèmes judiciaires respectifs.

title: Eurojust and ICC Prosecutor signed today a letter of understanding to increase co-operation
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 10 April 2007 Eurojust and ICC Prosecutor signed today a letter of understanding to increase co-operation. Mr Michael Kennedy, President of Eurojust, and Mr Luis Moreno-Ocampo, Prosecutor of the International Criminal Court (ICC), signed today a letter of understanding on co-operation. Eurojust, the European Union’s Judicial Body, has agreements with other EU bodies such as Europol and OLAF, but this is the first agreement signed with an international body. Eurojust and the Office of the Prosecutor have agreed to enhance contacts between them, to explore areas of co-operation and to exchange experiences of a non-operational nature. In particular, the agreement aims to promote the sharing of general and specific information about serious and organised crime that may be of mutual interest and benefit. The letter of understanding also expresses an intent to explore forging a formal co-operation agreement in the future. Both the ICC and Eurojust are located in the ARC building on the outskirts of The Hague. Michael Kennedy, the President of the College of Eurojust, was very pleased: ‘I am delighted that we are to develop a closer working relationship with our neighbours in the Office of the Prosecutor of the ICC.  Whilst we have very different roles and responsibilities I am sure that, where and when possible, we should do all we can to assist each other in cases of mutual interest and areas where we can draw upon each others expertise.’

title: OLAF and EUROJUST hold a Joint Seminar on Fraud and Corruption Affecting European Communities’ Financial Interests
text: Page ContentBrussels, 26 March 2007 The European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) and EUROJUST are holding their first joint seminar on “Fraud and Corruption Affecting European Communities’ Financial Interests” in Brussels, 26-27 March 2007, in the premises of the Committee of Regions. The seminar emphasizes the co-operation and assistance provided by OLAF and EUROJUST to national authorities to fight against fraud and corruption affecting the European Communities’ financial interests. Following the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding on 14 April 2003 between the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) and Eurojust, the European Union’s Judicial Cooperation Unit, which put in place the structure for their close co-operation in the fight against fraud, corruption and other criminal offences and illegal activities affecting the European Communities’ financial interests, this two-day seminar examines corruption, preventative measures such as the development of an interactive e-mailing system and electronic whistle-blowing and case studies of international corruption. Improving relations with national authorities and other EU bodies, namely the European Judicial Network (EJN), Europol and the future co-operation between them all is a high priority. The Chairman of the OLAF Supervisory Committee, Ms Rosalind Wright, OLAF Director-General, Mr F.H. Brüner, President of Eurojust, Mr Michael Kennedy, Vice-President of Eurojust, Mr Lopes da Mota, Eurojust National Members from different EU Member States, Chief Prosecutors, fiscal anticorruption representatives, OLAF magistrates and OLAF investigators are participating in the joint seminar. Mr Siim Kallas, Vice-President of the European Commission responsible for Administrative Affairs, Audit and Anti-Fraud stated: “This seminar brings together two relatively recent actors in dealing with cases of fraud and crime at EU level. The conference today is a signal that there has been a significant improvement of the daily operational co-operation between OLAF and Eurojust; the European citizen rightly expects an effective European response.” Mr Kennedy, President of the College of Eurojust, commented on the seminar: “This first joint seminar will be a milestone in our history, and in the co-operation between our organisations. We are both fighting against serious and organised crime. The fact that Eurojust is now part of the OAFCN network will enable us to inform the general public and the professionals better and more accurately about ourjoint goals and achievements”. The Director-General of OLAF, Mr F.H. Brüner, welcomes this development of practical arrangements in the co-operation and the exchange of information between Eurojust and OLAF. Concerning the request of Eurojust to join the OLAF Anti-Fraud Communicators’ Network (OAFCN), approved by the full body of the OAFCN, Mr Brüner stated: “I am confident that this joint seminar and the next OAFCN meeting will be a good starting point for future dialogue and co-operation”. title: Séminaire commun d’OLAF et d’EUROJUST sur la fraude et la corruption affectant les intérêts financiers des Communautés européennes
text: Page ContentBruxelles, le 26 mars 2007 L’Office européen de lutte anti-fraude  (OLAF) et EUROJUST organisent leur premier séminaire commun sur « La fraude et la corruption affectant les intérêts financiers des Communautés européennes » à Bruxelles, les 26-27 mars 2007 dans les locaux du Comité des régions. Le séminaire met l’accent sur la coopération et l’assistance fournies par  OLAF et EUROJUST aux autorités nationales pour lutter contre la fraude et la corruption qui affectent les intérêts financiers des Communautés européennes.  Suite à la signature, le 14 avril 2003, du protocole d’entente entre l’Office européen de lutte anti-fraude (OLAF) et EUROJUST, l’unité de coopération judiciaire de l’Union européenne, qui établissait la structure de leur coopération étroite dans la lutte contre la fraude, la corruption et tout autre acte criminel ou activités illégales affectant les intérêts financiers des Communautés européennes, ce séminaire de deux jours examine la corruption, les mesures préventives telles que le développement d’un système de courrier électronique interactif, la dénonciation électronique et des études de cas de corruption internationale.  L’amélioration des relations avec les autorités nationales et d’autres organismes de l’UE, à savoir le réseau judiciaire européen (RJE), Europol et la future coopération entre eux est une priorité élevée. La Présidente du Comité de surveillance de l’OLAF, Mme Rosalind Wright, le Directeur général de l’OLAF M. F.H. Brüner, le Président d’Eurojust M. Michael Kennedy, le vice-président d’EUROJUST, M. Lopes da Mota, des membres nationaux d’Eurojust de différents États membres de l’UE, des procureurs en chef, des représentants de la lutte contre la corruption fiscale, des magistrats d’OLAF et des enquêteurs d’OLAF participeront au séminaire commun.  M. Siim Kallas, Vice-président de la Commission européenne, responsable des affaires administratives, audit et anti-fraude déclare : « Ce séminaire regroupe deux acteurs relativement récents de la lutte contre la fraude et le crime au niveau de l’UE. La conférence d’aujourd’hui démontre une amélioration notable de la coopération opérationnelle quotidienne entre OLAF et EUROJUST ; le citoyen européen exige, à juste titre, une réponse efficace au niveau européen. M. Kennedy, Président du Collège d’Eurojust fait le commentaire suivant au sujet du séminaire : « Ce premier séminaire commun marquera une étape décisive dans notre histoire et la coopération entre nos deux organisations. Nous luttons toutes deux contre le crime grave et le crime organisé. Le fait qu’Eurojust fait maintenant partie du réseau OAFCN nous permettra de mieux informer le grand public et les professionnels sur nos objectifs et nos réalisations communs. » Le Directeur général de l’OLAF, M. F.H. Brüner, se félicite de ces nouvelles dispositions pratiques en matière de coopération et de l’échange d’informations entre EUROJUST et OLAF. En ce qui concerne la candidature d’EUROJUST au réseau de communicateurs anti-fraude de l’OLAF (OLAF Anti-Fraud Communicators’ Network, OAFCN), qui a été acceptée par l’OAFCN au grand complet, M. Brüner déclare : « Je suis certain que ce séminaire commun et la prochaine réunion de l’OAFCN sera un bon point de départ pour le dialogue et la coopération à venir. » Mr Joannes THUY, Press Officer & SpokespersonEUROJUST, Maanweg 174, 2516 AB, The Hague, The NetherlandsTel +31 70 412 5508 - Fax +31 70 412 5005E-mail: jthuy[AT]eurojust.europa.eu Maximilian StrotmannPorte-parole administration, audit et anti-fraudeTél : + 32 (0) 2 299 98 98E-mail : maximilian.strotmann[AT]ec.europa.euM. title: Europe-wide serial killer case successfully co-ordinated by Eurojust
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 19 March 2007 Eurojust co-ordinated the successful outcome of a Europe-wide serial killer case with at least 19 victims and involving Spain, Germany and France. Thanks to successful investigations by the Spanish authorities, an alleged serial killer has been arrested. A German lorry driver (48 years old), who traveled regularly from Germany to mainly France and Spain, is suspected of having committed at least 19 murders and attempted murders between 1974, when the suspect was 15 years old, and 2006. Most of the victims were prostitutes. Recorded by a CCTV camera from a private Spanish company while disposing of one of his victims, the man was identified and arrested by German police following a request by the Spanish authorities for mutual legal assistance and the issuance of a European Arrest Warrant by the Spanish authorities. When confronted with the evidence, the suspect confessed to five other murders in Spain and France as well as one in Germany, when the suspect was 15 years old and the victim was 14 years old. The murderer committed his crimes in the regions of Barcelona and Figueras (Spain), Plauen (Germany) and Saintes and Reims (France). Other unsolved cases in Europe are being investigated. In addition to Spain, France and Germany, there may be other countries involved, leading to a conflict of jurisdiction. Therefore, there is an urgent need for an exchange of information and co-ordination of proceedings, especially regarding time pressure for an indictment as the suspect is under pre-trial detention. Therefore the German prosecution office has asked for the support of Eurojust. Eurojust, the European Union’s Judicial Co-operation Unit, is composed of 27 National Members from all EU Member States. Providing the national authorities with its expertise in criminal matters, Eurojust also offers a forum for direct exchange of information by the investigating national authorities and – most important – is able to give recommendations to national authorities on further proceedings, such as, in this case, on which country is better placed to prosecute. During a very productive and focused co-ordination meeting on 14 March at the Eurojust premises in The Hague, the involved National Members discussed with their national colleagues from Spanish, French and German police, as well as with prosecutors and judges, the state of affairs and existing problems, and considered all relevant arguments, including the interests of the victims and their relatives. By a unanimous decision of the 27 National Members of the College of Eurojust, according to Article 7 of the Council Decision of 28 February 2002, Eurojust has decided that Germany is best placed to prosecute all facts included in this case.

title: Successful co-operation and co-ordination activities have led to the dismantling of a credit card fraud network in Romania
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 27 March 2007 On the evening of 26 March, two individuals of Romanian nationality were handed over to the French judicial authorities as the subjects of a European Arrest Warrant (EAW) for being the heads of an organised fraud and criminal network, which was issued by the examining magistrates of the Organised Crime Authority of Lyon (JIRS) to their Romanian counterparts in Craiova. Following questioning in Lyon, France, during June 2006 of three Romanian nationals in possession of large amounts of money, a search and subsequent investigation led to the discovery of a network of international trafficking in counterfeit credit cards. In order to co-ordinate the activities of the police and judicial authorities in Romania and Italy, as well as Germany, Austria and Spain, the JIRS contacted Eurojust. In December 2006, Eurojust organised a co-ordination meeting with the competent authorities of the Member States involved. Investigators and magistrates from those countries worked on an operational strategy for co-ordinated and simultaneous actions. Analytical work provided by Europol has offered the opportunity to clarify the different aspects of the case, to identify other actors involved in these criminal activities and to gather evidence showing links to various countries. An action plan to co-ordinate the execution of the operations in Romania and Italy on 5 February 2007 led to the dismantling of the network. Simultaneous house searches and questioning led to the discovery of an office in the Craiova region of Romania, in which a number of counterfeit cards and special devices used to commit fraud involving cash withdrawal machines were found. Two of the main suspects were arrested on European Arrest Warrants. The call for assistance to Europol and Eurojust from the start of the case has permitted both European organisations to support the French authorities in the most effective way possible and question the presumed perpetrators. All those involved want to underline the excellent assistance provided by the Romanian authorities during the operation in Craiova. The two individuals who were the subject of the EAW will soon appear before the examining magistrate in Lyon and risk being sentenced up to ten years’ imprisonment and a fine of € 1 million. These results highlight how first-class co-operation between the different Member States can be achieved on a European level by Eurojust and Europol working together with magistrates and police officers in the 27 Member States of the European Union and the importance of analytical structures and capacity in the effective co-ordination of such activities. This case demonstrates that the development of such co-operation tools helps to establish connections between criminal acts that are organised and controlled outside of the European cities in which these acts occur and which cause the citizens a considerable amount of insecurity.

title: Eurojust’s future housing in The Hague
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 21 March 2007 Today, 21 March 2007, a manifesto about the future housing of Eurojust in The Hague was presented and signed. Eurojust is currently located in a wing of the “Arc” building on the outskirts of The Hague. The other two wings are occupied by the International Criminal Court. As both international organisations are growing both in number of staff and workload, there is an urgent need for a larger building or buildings. Eurojust also pointed out, during meetings with the Dutch authorities and the City of The Hague, the need to be located more closely to Europol to improve the co-operation between both organisations.  The manifesto states the position of the Dutch authorities and the City of The Hague regarding future housing of Eurojust and other international organisations in the “World Forum Park” in the city centre. Today, this manifesto was signed, during a ceremony in the Ministry of Justice, by Mrs Albayrak, State Secretary of the Ministry of Justice, Mr Deetman, Mayor of The Hague, and Mr Jägers, Director General of the Government Building Agency (RGD). Mr Kennedy, President of the College of Eurojust, showed his appreciation for this initiative:  “I am delighted that today the Dutch Ministry of Justice and the Municipality of The Hague have made a clear joint commitment to confirming Eurojust’s future premises will be located close to Europol’s new building in the World Forum Park in the City of The Hague.  Some months ago we submitted Eurojust’s Programme of Requirements for our new premises to the Ministry of Justice and to the City of The Hague.  I am extremely pleased that this issue is being actively progressed and I know Eurojust is looking forward to working in partnership with both authorities to achieve our combined objectives.”

title: Gemeinschaftsseminar von OLAF und EUROJUST über die Auswirkungen von Betrug und Korruption auf die Finanzinteressen der Europäischen Gemeinschaften
text: Page ContentBrüssel, 26. März 2007 Am 26. und 27. März 2007 findet in Brüssel am Sitz des Ausschusses der Regionen das erste Gemeinschaftsseminar des Europäischen Amtes für Betrugsbekämpfung (OLAF) und EUROJUST statt. Das Seminar steht im Zeichen der von OLAF und EUROJUST den nationalen Behörden gebotenen Unterstützung im Kampf gegen Betrug und Korruption mit Auswirkungen auf die Finanzinteressen der Europäischen Gemeinschaften. Nach Unterzeichnung einer Absichtserklärung zwischen dem Europäischen Amt für Betrugsbekämpfung (OLAF) und der Europäischen Stelle für justizielle Zusammenarbeit (EUROJUST) über den Rahmen ihrer engen Zusammenarbeit im Kampf gegen Betrug, Korruption und andere deliktische Handlungen und illegale Aktivitäten mit Auswirkungen auf die Finanzinteressen der Europäischen Gemeinschaften am 14. April 2003 (siehe Pressemitteilung OLAF/11/2003) befasst sich dieses zweitägige Seminar mit Korruption, Präventivmaßnahmen wie die Entwicklung interaktiver E-Mail-Systeme, elektronischem Whistleblowing und Fallstudien zur internationalen Korruption.   Höchste Priorität gilt der Verbesserung der Beziehungen zu den nationalen Behörden und anderen EU Organen, namentlich dem Europäischen Justiziellen Netz (EJN), Europol und der zukünftigen gegenseitigen Zusammenarbeit. Die Vorsitzende des OLAF Überwachungsausschusses, Rosalind Wright, OLAF Generaldirektor F.H. Brüner, Eurojust Präsident Michael Kennedy, EUROJUST Vizepräsident Lopes da Mota, nationale Mitglieder von Eurojust aus verschiedenen EU Ländern, Oberstaatsanwälte, Vertreter aus dem Bereich der Steuerbetrugsbekämpfung, OLAF Richter und OLAF Ermittler nehmen am Gemeinschaftsseminar teil.  Herr Siim Kallas, Vizepräsident der Europäischen Kommission mit Verantwortung für Verwaltung, Audit und Betrugsbekämpfung, erklärt: „Dieses Seminar vereint zwei recht neue Akteure im Kampf gegen Betrug und Kriminalität auf EU Ebene. Die heutige Konferenz ist ein Zeichen für die bedeutende Verbesserung der alltäglichen operativen Zusammenarbeit zwischen OLAF und EUROJUST. Die europäischen Bürgerinnen und Bürger erwarten zu Recht ein wirksames europäisches Vorgehen.“ Herr Kennedy, Präsident des Eurojust Kollegiums, meint zum Seminar: „Dieses erste Gemeinschaftsseminar ist ein Meilenstein in unserer Geschichte und der Zusammenarbeit unserer zwei Organisationen. Wir kämpfen beide gegen die schwere und organisierte Kriminalität. Dank der OAFCN Mitgliedschaft von Eurojust können wir nun die Öffentlichkeit und die Fachleute besser und genauer über unsere gemeinsamen Ziele und Erfolge informieren.“ OLAF Generaldirektor F.H. Brüner begrüßt diese Entwicklung bei den praktischen Aspekten der Zusammenarbeit und beim Informationsaustausch zwischen EUROJUST und OLAF. Bezüglich des Antrags von EUROJUST auf Beitritt zum OLAF Netz der Kommunikationsbeauftragten im Bereich der Betrugsbekämpfung (OLAF Anti-Fraud Communicators’ Network, OAFCN), dem das OAFCN einstimmig statt gab, erklärt Herr Brüner: „Ich bin zuversichtlich, dass dieses Gemeinschaftsseminar und die nächste OAFCN Sitzung ein guter Ausgangspunkt für den zukünftigen Dialog und die Zusammenarbeit sind.“   Maximilian StrotmannSprecher für Verwaltung, Audit und BetrugsbekämpfungTel +32 (0) 2 299 98 98E-mail: maximilian.strotmann[AT]ec.europa.euJoannes THUYPressereferent und SprecherEUROJUSTTel +31 70 412 5508Fax +31 70 412 5005E-mail info[AT]eurojust.europa.euP.O. title: Eurojust held a co-ordination meeting on international VAT carousel fraud estimated at € 2.1 billion and involving 18 Member States
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 13 March 2007 Eurojust hosted a large co-ordination meeting between representatives from 18 Member States, Switzerland and the Netherlands Antilles. The Arab Emirates also assisted in the co-ordination of the case. The case was brought to Eurojust by the UK Desk, at the request of the customs prosecution offices. The case was adopted as a ‘College case’, meaning that the College of Eurojust has a greater range of powers based on Article 7 of the Eurojust Decision. Eurojust identified the affected countries and invited them to this meeting. Mr Phil Hicks, Assistant to the National Member for the United Kingdom, chaired the meeting and commented afterwards: ‘The purpose of the meeting was to share information with those Member States that have been affected by the criminal activities that have led to money being deposited in the bank in Dubai or appeared to be in the possession of information linked to this case. Some of the Member States who participated in the meeting are well aware of criminal activity in their country; others were not, but received information during this meeting. Prosecutors and tax investigators from 18 out of the 27 Member States were present as well as the National Desks of Eurojust. In addition, the meeting was attended by a representative from Switzerland and information was presented from the prosecution authorities of the Netherland Antilles. By its nature, these crimes are difficult to trace because of the many money flows, but by sharing information in this way, we can stay one step ahead of the criminals and bring then to justice more effectively.’ A large sum of money was seized in the Arab Emirates, whose authorities have been assisting in this case. The main criminal activity involved money laundering - the depositing of money first in a bank in the Netherland Antilles and subsequently in a bank in Dubai. These assets were obtained from various VAT carousels in different Member States: Expensive commodities were purchased in one Member State and exported and sold in another without payment of VAT to the tax authorities. Soon after this, the companies involved ‘disappeared’ without a trace. The meeting identified all relevant investigations and prosecutions in the EU, provided an opportunity for an exchange of information, encouraged new investigations and prosecutions to be taken up in other countries and explored how to co-operate successfully in each other's actions.

title: José Luis Lopes da Mota, National Member for Portugal elected as new Vice-President
text: Page ContentDuring the plenary meeting of the College of Eurojust on 15 February 2006, Mr Lopes da Mota was elected to replace Ms Ulrike Haberl-Schwarz, who will continue her career in Austria, as President of the Court of Leoben, Styria. She was elected Vice-President in January 2004. “I am delighted that my colleague and friend Mr Jose Luis Lopes da Mota has been elected Vice-President to the College of Eurojust. Mr Lopes da Mota has been the Portuguese National Member since Eurojust began as a Provisional Unit in March 2001 and so he has an intimate knowledge of our organisation. Indeed he has led many of the important initiatives which established Eurojust’s infrastructure, especially in the areas of information technology, our Case Management System and data protection. It will be a great advantage for Eurojust as his election will enable him to continue this excellent commitment as Vice-President of the College”, said Michael Kennedy, President of the College. Together with Michael Kennedy and Vice-President Roelof Jan Manschot, Vice-President José Luis Lopes da Mota will represent the College, substitute for the President in his absence and assist with management of the work of the College and monitor the daily work ensured by Eurojust’s Administrative Director. José Luis Lopes da Mota has 28 years’ experience in the judiciary as a prosecutor and as an assistant to the Portuguese Prosecutor General where he was responsible for matters related to management of the prosecution services at a national level and for international co-operation. He was a lecturer at the Portuguese national school for magistrates and a Deputy Minister of Justice in charge of a range of issues including European affairs. He joined Eurojust from its early beginnings in Brussels. José Luís Lopes da Mota (Photo in hi-res available)

title: Eurojust celebrates its five years of existence
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 6 March 2007 The European Council’s Decision of 28 February 2002 on the setting up of Eurojust with a view to reinforcing the fight against serious crime was published on 6 March 2002 in the Official Journal of the European Communities. On 15 and 16 October 1999, the European Council held a special meeting in Tampere, Finland, dedicated to the creation of an area of freedom, security and justice in the European Union by concentrating on establishing immigration and asylum policy based on solidarity and on the re-enforcement of the fight against trans-border crime by consolidating co-operation among authorities. To reinforce the fight against serious organised crime, the European Council agreed that a unit, EUROJUST, should be established composed of national prosecutors, magistrates, or police officers of equivalent competence, detached from each Member State according to its legal system. A provisional Judicial Co-operation Unit was set up following a Council Decision of 14 December 2000. This ‘Pro-Eurojust’ unit was working in the Council building in Brussels until December 2002, when the unit moved to The Hague. On 29 March 2003, Eurojust’s seat in The Hague was officially inaugurated by EU Commissioner Vittorino, Greek Justice Minister Petsalnikos, Dutch Justice Minister Donner and the President of the College of Eurojust, Michael Kennedy. On 1 May 2004, the 10 new Member States appointed 10 National Members to enlarge the College of Eurojust to 25 National Members. On 1 January 2007, the National Members from Bulgaria and Romania were welcomed to join the College of Eurojust. During these first five years, Eurojust concluded co-operation agreements with Europol, Norway, Iceland, Romania and the USA. As a result of these agreements, a Liaison Prosecutor from Norway and a Liaison Magistrate from Romania were permanently based at Eurojust commencing in 2005. A Liaison Magistrate from the USA joined Eurojust in 2006.  Eurojust has built up contact points in the judicial authorities beyond the EU, in Albania, Argentina, Croatia, Canada, FYROM, Japan, Liechtenstein, Russia, Montenegro, Serbia, Switzerland, Turkey, Ukraine and the IberRed network in Latin America.   The caseload of the College increased from 192 cases in 2001 to 771 cases in 2006, meaning that the judicial authorities from the Member States are more often referring their complex and cross-border cases to Eurojust to facilitate and co-ordinate the process of bringing criminals to trial while respecting the different judicial systems of the 27 Member States.  An administrative team supports the work of the College and the National Members. The number of post-holders increased from 7 in 2002 to 93 in 2006.   Franco Frattini, Vice-President of the European Commission responsible for Freedom, Security and Justice, commented on the anniversary:"EU citizens understand perfectly well that the increasing phenomenon of cross-border organised crime, such as trafficking in arms, drugs and human beings, counterfeiting and child pornography can only be efficiently addressed at European level and to that end citizens demand enhanced cooperation between law enforcement and judicial authorities. Eurojust's role", Vice-President Frattini continued, "has over the past five years ever-increased and has now developed into being an indispensable and efficient tool ensuring smooth, non-bureaucratic, but legally sound cooperation in the fight against terrorism and all serious forms of organised crime, as the statistics clearly demonstrate. I will present an evaluation of the role of Eurojust and a reflection on its future in a Communication which I will publish in September of this year. However, Eurojust can continue to rely on my personal and the Commission's commitment to facilitating its important work and I wish them all the best in the years to come, in the interest and security of EU citizens."The President of the College, Michael Kennedy, said he was very pleased to look back on these five years of intensive work: “It is hard to believe that five years have passed since the concept of Eurojust - one experienced judge or prosecutor from each EU state working together on a permanent basis - became a reality. Much progress has been made in that time. A great deal has been achieved thanks to the efforts of all who have been National Members and our excellent administrative staff. It has been a privilege to be involved from the very beginning and a great honour for me to represent the College of Eurojust. However in coming years there is much more to be done if we are to continue to increase effectiveness and succeed in the fight against serious cross-border crime in Europe and elsewhere. All in Eurojust look forward in the coming years to building on the excellent foundations which have been laid since 2002.”

title: Eurojust co-ordinated action ‘Baltico’ in six countries against armed robberies
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 21 February 2007 Eurojust successfully co-ordinated the execution of 35 European Arrest Warrants (EAWs) for armed robberies committed in Italy. The EAWs were executed simultaneously in six countries. Eurojust and Europol co-ordinated a large action involving several police and judicial forces in Italy, Estonia, Lithuania, Finland, Spain, France and Germany, leading yesterday to the arrest of several key members of a criminal organisation responsible for armed robberies committed over the last two years in more than 200 up-market jewellery shops throughout Europe. Commencing June 2006, Eurojust scheduled meetings in The Hague and Italy to co-ordinate the different cases between Eurojust, Europol and the Member States involved in order to initiate a common approach by all parties to bring the criminals to trial in an effective way. During this meeting, it became clear that Italy was best placed to investigate and prosecute all cases. Parties agreed to fully support the Italian authorities during the investigations. Since December 2006, the Estonian authorities had been preparing a police action in co-operation with Eurojust, Europol and the Italian Carabinieri of Milan. An Italian judge issued 35 European Arrest Warrants to six Member States: 25 to Estonia, 4 to Finland, 1 to Lithuania, 2 to France, 2 to Spain and 1 to Germany. The EAWs were simultaneously executed yesterday and led to the arrest of all key figures of the criminal organisation. The Deputy National Member for Italy, Ms Manfredda, and the National Member for Estonia, Mr Sepp, commented today: ‘This success shows how very good co-operation between Eurojust and Europol, according to the agreement between both organisations, and the authorities in the Member States is bringing criminals to justice, following appropriate practice and with respect to each country’s judicial system. The enlargement of the EU is bringing more freedom of movement to people, and also more possibilities to work together in the fight against organised cross-border crime. The new EU Member States demonstrated a willingness to co-operate. Now the way is prepared for the surrender of the criminals. For the Estonian police forces, this was the biggest operation on a European level, and they performed on a very high level’.   Ms Manfredda, Deputy National Member for Italy also emphasised the perfect synergy that took place between the Italian desk at Eurojust and the Italian national correspondent, at the Second Office of the Ministry of Justice in Rome, who are dealing with criminal matters.

title: Eurojust Co-ordinated Surrender of Ex-BAWAG banker Elsner
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 13 February 2007 Eurojust successfully co-ordinated the surrender of Mr Elsner from France to Austria following a complex procedure. BACKGROUND INFORMATION: The case involves a huge bank fraud in Austria. The suspect was the former head of the BAWAG bank, one of the largest banking groups in Austria. The 71-year-old man is the key figure in a large banking scandal, involving at least € 1.700.000.000 (one billion seven hundred million Euro). He used the bank funds for speculative Caribbean investments.  Thanks a speedy overnight action, co-ordinated by the Austrian and French National Desks at Eurojust, the French judicial authorities arrested Mr Elsner on the morning of Tuesday 14 September 2006, based on a European Arrest Warrant (EAW) issued by the Austrian authorities. The Cour de Cassation decided in favour of the execution of the EAW, but due to alleged health problems of Mr Elsner, the surrender was suspended. On 29 January 2007, Eurojust organised a co-ordination meeting in Vienna regarding the final steps in the procedure. During this meeting, judicial authorities from Austria and France met with the competent prosecutor for international co-operation from the Austrian Justice Ministry. As a follow-up to that meeting, a detailed action plan was set up to conduct the co-ordinated action which took place today. This morning, medical experts in cardiology from Austria and France travelled to the hospital in St. Laurent-sur-Var near Nice to examine the state of Mr Elsner’s health. They gave their approval for immediate transportation to Austria. In the early afternoon, Mr Elsner was brought to the airport of Marseille, where an ambulance plane was waiting. He is now flying under police escort to Vienna. The Austrian and French National Desks at Eurojust were able to achieve this result thanks to their close working relationship, expertise and multilingual skills.  Dr Ulrike Haberl-Schwarz, the Austrian National Member, commented: ‘This action could not have been possible without the expertise and assistance of Eurojust. The National Members are on stand-by 24/24, 7/7 for important and difficult cases. The fact that the National Members are always in close contact with each other offers the possibility to act both quickly and in conformity with the different legislations in the EU Member States.’

title: Czech National Member at Eurojust re-appointed
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 6 February 2007 Mr Pavel Zeman, National Member for the Czech Republic at Eurojust, was re-appointed by the Czech authorities because of his highly-valued work On Thursday 1 February, the Czech National Desk hosted a working visit by Ms Renata Vesecká, General Prosecutor for the Czech Republic. She was accompanied by Mr Zdeněk Koudelka and Mr Karel Černovský, Deputy Prosecutor Generals. The delegation participated in a College plenary meeting, where Ms Vesecká explained the judicial system of the Czech Republic and answered questions raised by the National Members. The General Prosecutor spoke about the importance of her visit: ‘My visit to Eurojust is very important. The importance of Eurojust is growing, seeing the globalisation that also takes place in Europe. In the same way, organised crime is working without borders. Therefore it’s important that the prosecution offices are able to work without frontiers too. Also important is the speed with which criminality can be tackled. Eurojust plays a big role in this. Besides this rather practical impact, I believe exchange of information and knowledge is very important. I enjoyed the personal contacts between the National Members at Eurojust, and this is leading to an in-depth co-operation.’ ‘This year, Mr Zeman’s secondment to Eurojust will end’, she continued, ‘But since I am fully aware of the important role he is playing, I can already unveil to you that I have proposed to the Minister of Justice to prolong his appointment to Eurojust. The Minister has given this mandate, so I am pleased to announce that Mr Zeman will stay at Eurojust. I also can add that I asked the Minister to appoint a Deputy, and I proposed Mrs Novotná for this position. We are expecting the Minister’s decision any day now, but I am sure this will be positive.’ In 2009, the Czech Republic will hold the EU Presidency. Therefore, Eurojust will allow trainees to work at the National Desks. Also this year, specialists and professionals from the Czech Republic will visit Eurojust to learn more about its work and aims. Mr Mike Kennedy, President of the College of Eurojust, commented: ‘I was delighted to welcome the Czech Prosecutor General and her two deputies to Eurojust. Her visit will help to build trust and confidence in Eurojust and to develop a wider knowledge of our work in the Czech Republic. It will also help Czech prosecutors to understand how we can create effective mutual co-operation amongst the legal systems within the EU.’

title: Eurojust co-ordinated large tax fraud and money laundering case involving five Member States
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 20 October 2008 On 14 October 2008, under the supervision of the Dutch National Prosecution Service for Serious Financial Economical and Environmental Crime. (Functioneel Parket), the FIOD-ECD carried out searches in connection with a judicial investigation of tax fraud, counterfeiting, money laundering and participation in a criminal organisation. The searches were carried out in Amsterdam, Utrecht and Zutphen. Seven suspects were arrested. Business files, computers and telephones were seized.The FIOD-ECD (Fiscale Inlichtingen en Opsporingsdienst - Economische Controledienst) is the Dutch Finance Ministry's special investigations unit. As well as dealing with tax fraud, the unit investigates bankruptcy, fraud and money laundering. It contributes to the fight against organised crime by mapping out money flows of criminal organisations, often in co-operation with sister organisations abroadIt was suspected that cooking equipment and knife sets were distributed to companies in Spain, Italy, Germany and France while avoiding import and customs tax. In addition, large quantities of money were laundered. There was a presumption that deliveries to foreign companies not took place, but that this was deluded by means of false invoices and payments by foreign companies, made possible by transferring cash money abroad. The goods were sold in the Netherlands and in other European countries on the black market. Investigators state that more than € 22 million was laundered and € 5 million in tax was lost. Searches were carried out not only in the Netherlands but also in foreign countries. The NL Desk at Eurojust organised co-ordination meetings to have co-ordinated judicial and police actions in the Member States involved. Also Europol has played a co-ordinating role in the investigation. In addition to the Netherlands, also Belgium, Germany, Italy and Spain were involved in the investigations and searches. The Dutch Tax Authority has confiscated, among other things, automobiles, residences, household effects and made tax assessments for approximately € 6 million.

title: Large skimming network dismantled
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 20 November 2008 Eurojust and Europol played an important role in the dismantling of a large international skimming network involving nine European Union Member States. On 19 November 2008, 15 persons suspected of being part of a skimming network were arrested throughout Europe: 7 in Belgium, 6 in Romania and 2 in Spain. The international operation was directed from Belgium by the Federal Prosecution Office in Brussels, in cooperation with the Prosecution Office, the Investigating Magistrate and the Federal Police of Dendermonde, Belgium, and with the support of Europol and Eurojust. A total of 34 house searches took place: 9 in Belgium, 20 in Romania, 2 in Spain, 1 in Germany and 2 in Ireland/United Kingdom. The criminal offences were committed in Romania, the Netherlands, Italy, Germany, Ireland, the United Kingdom, Spain, and Cyprus. Outside the European Union offences were committed in Turkey, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Dominican Republic, and Morocco. The investigations and prosecutions took place in Belgium, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Romania, Spain, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom, Australia and Canada. As a coordinated approach in both EU and non-EU countries was needed, the Belgian authorities referred the case to Eurojust and Europol in August 2008. Several coordination meetings took place at both institutions in The Hague between September and November 2008. Police officers, judges and prosecutors from the Member States concerned were either present or participated in the meetings through videoconferencing. BACKGROUND In this case, “skimming” crimes took place where the perpetrator places a device over the card slot of an automatic cash distribution machine, which reads the magnetic strip as the users pass their cards through it. These devices are often used in conjunction with a pinhole camera to read the user's PIN code at the same time.
