title: European-wide network of people smugglers dismantled
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 09 June 2009 ​Forty-six persons, suspected of being part of a people-smuggling network, were arrested today throughout Europe in an operation supported by Europol and Eurojust involving several countries. Arrests took place in Belgium, France, Germany, Greece, Italy and Switzerland as a result of investigations and after a number of house searches. All suspects are said to be involved in the clandestine smuggling of a large number of illegal immigrants into and within the European Union. Consequently, a number of illegal immigrants have also been arrested in various Member States. The police and judicial operations, code-named ‘Operation Ticket to Ride’, targeted a network, primarily consisting of Iraqi and former Iraqi nationals, which facilitated the illegal immigration of citizens from Iraq and from other countries, such as Afghanistan, into and within Europe. Europol experts prepared various intelligence reports, facilitated the exchange of information, and co-ordinated the police operations. Europol also hosted several operational meetings in the course of the operation. The main suspects and new criminal links were discovered by Europol in close co-operation with national experts after in-depth analysis. At the request of the Italian investigating magistrates, Eurojust was involved in assisting the co-ordination of the investigations and the exchange of information between the Member States involved. Eurojust dealt with the issuing of European Arrest Warrants and also hosted a coordination meeting. The joint operation was initiated in Rome, where an international coordination centre was set up by the Italian State Police. Experts and liaison officers from the various EU Member States were also present. During the operation, Europol was represented by two experts. The network was responsible for recruiting the illegal immigrants, mainly in Iraq, before transporting them to various EU Member States. Each of the persons smuggled is believed to have paid between 4,000 and 8,000 US dollars to reach Italy, depending on the means of transportation. It is believed that this network is responsible for smuggling more than 5,000 persons between December 2006 and June 2009. The money was normally paid via wire transfer. The illegal immigrants usually travelled in cramped conditions in trucks, camper vans, coaches or boats from Iraq to Europe via Turkey. Some of the illegal immigrants also used forged or counterfeited travel documents. For more information, please contact: EUROPOL: Mr. Soren Kragh Pedersen, Chief of Media/PR, Office +31 70 302 5118 soren.pedersen[AT]europol.europa.euEUROJUST: Mr. Joannes Thuy, Press Officer and Spokesperson, Office +31 70 412 5508 jthuy[AT]eurojust.europa.eu

title: High-level delegation from Albania visits Eurojust
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 29 May 2009 On 27 May, a high-level delegation from Albania, accompanied by members of the Belgian Federal Prosecutor’s Office, visited Eurojust. They were received by Ms Michèle Coninsx, Eurojust’s Vice-President, Chair of the Counter-Terrorism Team and National Member for Belgium. The Albanian delegation was composed of Ms Ina Rama, General Prosecutor of Albania, Mr Sokol Stojani, Head of the Prosecutor General’s Investigation Office, Mr Perparim Kulluri, Prosecutor of Shkodra, and Ms Miranda Bushi, Chef de Cabinet of the General Prosecutor. The delegation from Belgium was composed of Messrs Eric Bisschop and Thomas Lamiroy, Federal Magistrates in the Federal Prosecutor’s Office, and Mr André Nys, Belgian Liaison Officer in Albania. The purpose of the meeting was to introduce Eurojust to the guests and to provide them with an overview of Eurojust’s work and functions. The visit was organised by the Belgian Liaison Officer in Albania, Mr Nys, and coordinated by the Federal Magistrate, Mr Bisschop. The visit took place in the framework of the Belgian government’s action plan for reacting against travelling organised criminal gangs, in close cooperation with its privileged partners: Albania, Italy and the USA. This visit coincided with the preparation for strengthening Eurojust’s relationships with the Western Balkans. Ms Coninsx welcomed the delegation on behalf of the Presidency of Eurojust. She gave an in-depth presentation on Eurojust, including actual casework involving Eurojust and the Member States. Ms Coninsx highlighted the importance of coordination in the fight against terrorism and all types of organised crime involving third States. Ms Malči Gabrijelčič, Chair of the External Relations Team and National Member for Slovenia, presented current agreements and cooperation with third States, and their added value to the operational work of Eurojust. After the visit, Ms Ina Rama thanked Eurojust and commented: “We are very grateful for this visit, which highlighted the need for cooperation and coordination in pursuing our common goals to fight against terrorism and organised crime. We have been thoroughly informed about Eurojust and we will prepare ourselves to comply with the requirements and conditions necessary to start negotiations in view of concluding a judicial cooperation agreement with Eurojust.” For more information, please contact: Mr Joannes THUY, Press Officer & SpokespersonEUROJUST, Maanweg 174, 2516 AB, The Hague, The NetherlandsTel +31 70 412 5508 - Fax +31 70 412 5005E-mail: jthuy[AT]eurojust.europa.eu

title: Eurojust Counter-Terrorism Seminar
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 11 May 2009 Eurojust, in conjunction with the Czech Presidency of the European Union, held a seminar on Counter-Terrorism issues. The seminar took place on 4 and 5 May 2009 in Prague, Czech Republic. The purpose of the seminar was the exchange of best practice and information among judicial and law enforcement authorities operating in the Western Balkans. Speakers from Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia were present and elaborated on the Western Balkans countries’ perspective. Keynote speakers at the seminar were Mr Ženíšek, Deputy Minister of Justice of the Czech Republic, Ms Lenka Ptáčova-Melicharová, Deputy Minister of Interior, Ms Renata Vesecká, Prosecutor General, Ms Michèle Coninsx, Vice-President of Eurojust and Chair of the Counter-Terrorism Team and Mr Pavel Zeman, National Member for the Czech Republic at Eurojust. In the first part of the seminar, the Western Balkans’ perspective was presented by several keynote speakers from the Western Balkans. The second day was devoted to the exchange of information and evidence gathering, with actual case examples and presentations. The seminar’s conclusions were presented by Mr Lopes da Mota, President of Eurojust. He mentioned the fruitful discussions that took place in the fight against terrorism. “We have to look into the future”, Mr Lopes da Mota said. He mentioned that there are always links between terrorism and organised crime, and the Member States have to cope with common difficulties, such as legal obstacles to the exchange of information and the gathering of evidence that can be used in court. At the end of the Seminar, Mr Pavel Zeman commented: “This seminar was a successful initiative, and one of the highlights of the Czech Presidency. Judicial and police professionals and practitioners from the European Union and the Western Balkans met and discussed experiences and best practice in the fight against terrorism. I believe this seminar will kick-start intensive cooperation between Eurojust and judicial authorities from the EU and the Western Balkans. This is what we hope to achieve.” For more information, please contact: Mr Joannes THUY, Press Officer & SpokespersonEUROJUST, Maanweg 174, 2516 AB, The Hague, The NetherlandsTel +31 70 412 5508 - Fax +31 70 412 5005E-mail: jthuy[AT]eurojust.europa.eu

title: Signing of the Memorandum of Understanding between Eurojust and the Iberoamerican Network of Judicial Cooperation in Civil and Criminal Matters (“Iber-RED”)
text: Page ContentLisbon, 04 May 2009 Today, a Memorandum of Understanding was signed between Eurojust and the Iberoamerican Network of Judicial Cooperation in Civil and Criminal Matters (“Iber-RED”). This Memorandum of Understanding represents a further step in the ever-increasing cooperation of judicial bodies – across continents – in the fight against serious forms of transnational crime. This Memorandum of Understanding demonstrates the commitment of Eurojust to increase its sphere of cooperation. Improving the exchange of information and the sharing of best practice between Eurojust and Iber-RED is essential in combating serious crime, since crime in general and in particular serious crime is increasingly becoming a cross-border and international phenomenon and, as such, can only be fought effectively if law enforcement and judicial bodies and authorities also enhance their cooperation across borders. Background information: Following meetings between Eurojust and representatives of Iber-RED on potential cooperation between Eurojust and Iber-RED, this Memorandum of Understanding was concluded. The main points of the Memorandum of Understanding deal with the designation of a central contact point by each party, the establishment of regular contacts between the parties, communication among the contact points, the exchange of experiences and information of a non-operational nature, the possibility to invite the other party to strategic meetings, and the possibility to invite the other party to professional trainings, seminars and workshops. Thus far, Eurojust has been involved in two cases involving Iber-RED. Iber-RED was created under the auspices of the Conference of Ministers of Justice, with the support provided by the Summit of Iberoamerican Heads of State and Government. The Secretariat General of Iber-RED holds coordination and management functions and is entitled to maintain contacts and exchange experiences with other judicial networks and international bodies involved in judicial international cooperation. Since 28 September 2006, the Secretariat General has been located in Madrid. Mr Victor Moreno Catena was elected its Secretary-General. After the ceremony, Mr Lopes da Mota commented: “It is a pleasure for me to sign, on behalf of Eurojust, this Memorandum of Understanding with Iber-RED, since one of the goals of both of our organisations is the improvement of judicial cooperation. Consequently, it is only natural that we are seeking to increase the cooperation between Eurojust and Iber-RED. This Memorandum of Understanding will allow us to exchange our experiences and best practice and benefit from each other’s knowledge and experience. It will also provide a basis for us to increase our joint efforts in the area of trainings and seminars. And it will particularly provide for a possibility for mutual invitations to tactical meetings. Finally, I would also like to express my thanks to all of you who have made it possible that the Memorandum of Understanding can be signed here today.” The President of Eurojust also expressed special thanks to Mr António Luís Santos Alves, former Deputy National Member for Portugal at Eurojust, who initiated the contacts between Iber-RED and Eurojust on the side of Eurojust and who was deeply involved in the negotiations. Sadly, Mr Santos Alves suddenly passed away and could not be present at the moment when the work he has done is honoured with the signature of this Memorandum of Understanding. For more information, please contact: Mr Joannes THUY, Press Officer & SpokespersonEUROJUST, Maanweg 174, 2516 AB, The Hague, The NetherlandsTel +31 70 412 5508 - Fax +31 70 412 5005E-mail: jthuy[AT]eurojust.europa.eu

title: Eurojust coordinates arrests in drug case
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 22 April 2009 Following coordination meetings at Eurojust, the Italian, Dutch and Colombian authorities made several coordinated and simultaneous arrests in a large case of trafficking in human beings in order to finance drug trafficking. This week, 62 suspects were arrested by the Italian police in a drug trafficking case. The case, involving Italy, the Netherlands and Colombia, was lead by the Antimafia Public Prosecutor of Naples. The criminals were acting as an international criminal organisation, trafficking human beings from Nigeria to the Netherlands, to finance their drug operations. This was the second step in a large case. In June 2008, the criminal organisation, based in Nigeria, was trafficking Nigerian women to Amsterdam, where they were seeking asylum. After arriving in a safe house, they were transported by the criminal organisation to Italy, France and Spain and forced into prostitution. With the money earned from prostitution, the criminals were able to buy large amounts of cocaine in Colombia, to be shipped to Europe. On the request of the Antimafia Public Prosecutor of Naples, Eurojust organised a coordination meeting in March 2009. The judicial authorities from Colombia and the Netherlands, and the Italian prosecutor and police officers, attended the meeting. In this meeting, by exchanging information and experiences, they paved the way for the arrests of suspects in Europe and Colombia, and identified all the legal and factual difficulties for extradition and surrender of the suspects after arrest. Thanks to the coordination meetings held at Eurojust, it was possible to prove the links between the trafficking in human beings, the exploitation of women and the financing of drug activities by criminals. Today, Mr Filippo Spiezia, Deputy National Member for Italy, commented: “We had very good cooperation with the Dutch authorities to open new investigations against Nigerian criminals based in Amsterdam. This cooperation supported the Italian interests in this important case, and we were able to coordinate between the Colombian and Italian judicial authorities. We identified the legal and practical problems, and we found solutions to overcome them for extradition and surrender of the suspects. We focused also on strategic objectives for judicial cooperation between Europe and Colombia, and other National Members at Eurojust were also involved. The fact that at Eurojust we have 27 prosecutors, one from each Member State, permanently based in The Hague, was highly appreciated by the Colombian authorities. We created a special bridge between Europe and Colombia, and this case will continue.” For more information, please contact: Mr Joannes THUY, Press Officer & SpokespersonEUROJUST, Maanweg 174, 2516 AB, The Hague, The NetherlandsTel +31 70 412 5508 - Fax +31 70 412 5005E-mail: jthuy[AT]eurojust.europa.eu

title: Eurojust tactical meeting on “LTTE” criminal activities
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 31 March 2009 On 30 and 31 March, Eurojust hosted a tactical meeting on the worldwide criminal activities of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE). Delegates from different Member States, non-EU countries including Sri Lanka, and Europol attended the meeting. The participants were welcomed by Mr José Luís Lopes da Mota, President of Eurojust and National Member for Portugal. The European Union Counter-Terrorism Coordinator, Mr Gilles de Kerchove, also attended the opening of the meeting. A keynote address was given by HE Mr Ravinatha P Aryasinha, Ambassador of Sri Lanka to Belgium, Luxembourg and the European Union: “The LTTE is not a Sri Lankan problem alone”, he said. “It remains a fundamental problem that all nations, big and small, developed and developing, rich and poor, militarily powerful and weak, in all corners of the world have to confront, if we are to succeed in what is referred to as the fight against terrorism.” The objectives of the meeting were outlined by Ms Michèle Coninsx, Vice-President of Eurojust and National Member for Belgium, who chaired the meeting. A Eurojust/Europol joint presentation on the LTTE and its criminal activities informed the participants on the current state of affairs. Presentations on the topic were also given by several delegations, followed by workshops on best practice and lessons learned from criminal investigations and prosecutions, and on the best approach to address this type of terrorism. After the meeting, Ms Coninsx commented: “The fight against terrorism worldwide is of vital importance: innocent victims are killed for terrorist purposes. With the exchange of experience, lessons learned and best practice as we did today, we gain more expertise and insight into the matter. And so, we can be more successful in the fight against terrorists and at the same time save lives of innocent people”. For more information, please contact: Mr Joannes THUY, Press Officer & SpokespersonEUROJUST, Maanweg 174, 2516 AB, The Hague, The NetherlandsTel +31 70 412 5508 - Fax +31 70 412 5005E-mail: jthuy[AT]eurojust.europa.eu

title: Belgian Justice Minister Stefaan De Clerck visits Eurojust
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 29 April 2009 Yesterday, Eurojust hosted a visit by HE Mr Stefaan De Clerck, Federal Minister of Justice of Belgium, HE Ambassador Yves Haesendonck, Permanent Representative of Belgium to the International Institutions in The Hague, and Members of the Justice Committee of the Belgian Chamber of Representatives. Mr Stefaan De Clerck is the Belgian Minister of Justice since 2008. He became a lawyer after obtaining a law degree in 1975 from the KUL. As a Member of the Belgian Parliament since 1990, he focused on justice reform and modernisation. He became Minister of Justice in 1995 but he and the Minister of the Interior resigned in 1998 following the short escape of Dutroux. In 1999, he was elected president of the CVP (Christian Democrats) and became mayor of Kortrijk. In 2003, he was elected Senator, and later he moved to the Flemish Parliament. Since 2007, he has a seat in the Belgian Senate. The Justice Committee of the Belgian Chamber of Representatives is composed of Members of the Belgian Parliament, and is chaired by Mrs Mia De Schamphelaere. Background Following the Council of Tampere in October 1999, Belgium, as well as Portugal, France and Sweden, were the four countries to introduce the initiative to set up Eurojust on 24 August 2000. During the Belgian Presidency of the EU in 2001, Eurojust was given its final structure. The Eurojust Decision, establishing Eurojust as a fully operational European Union body, was adopted on 28 February 2002. A new Eurojust Decision was agreed upon in July 2008, and approved by the Council in December 2008. The aim of this new Decision is to strengthen Eurojust in its fight against serious, organised and cross-border crimes by cooperating with and coordinating the actions of European judicial authorities. The powers granted by the new Eurojust Decision will lead to a necessary reinforcement of the National Desks at Eurojust; the extended powers of the National Members will lead to even more cases at Eurojust. During his visit to Eurojust, Minister De Clerck met with the President of Eurojust and National Member for Portugal, Mr José Luís Lopes da Mota, and then with Ms Michèle Coninsx, Vice-President of Eurojust and National Member for Belgium. Ms Coninsx is also chair of the College Counter-Terrorism Team. Following words of welcome by the President, Ms Coninsx presented the work and aims of Eurojust, and placed it in its historical context from 2001 to today. Other National Members participated in the visit and some gave examples of cases successfully managed by Eurojust on people smuggling and terrorism. Special attention was given to child protection and the contact point for child protection at Eurojust, an initiative taken by the former Belgian Justice Minister, HE Mme Onckelinx. The new Eurojust Decision on the strengthening of Eurojust was also presented and discussed. Minister De Clerck commented afterwards: “I am delighted that I was given the opportunity to visit Eurojust. This is Europe in concreto. My impression is that here we see Europe at work in close judicial as well as police cooperation. This means that now we are better equipped to cope with Europe-wide criminality and to tackle it in an effective way. Eurojust is a necessity and deserves our support. During the next Belgian Presidency in the second half of next year, we certainly will follow the same line: Belgium was one of the founders of Eurojust, and we will continue to support it. Belgium will be resolutely supportive to the role that Eurojust can and will play in the shaping and strengthening of the European judicial area, based on the new powers given to Eurojust by the JHA Ministerial Council of November 2008.” Mrs Mia De Schamphelaere, Chair of the Justice Committee of the Belgian Chamber of Representatives, added: “The Justice Committee of the Belgian Chamber of Representatives was very pleased with the visit to Eurojust and the insight given into the practical work of the Belgian National Member and other National Members. Eurojust is an essential link in safeguarding safety and security for European citizens. The Justice Committee will soon deal with the amendments to Belgian legislation that are necessary to give more powers to the Belgian magistrates at Eurojust, and to better align Belgian criminal law with European challenges.” At the end of the visit, Ms Coninsx commented: “This visit was timed perfectly, as Eurojust with the new Council Decision is going into a second phase. We were very pleased to welcome a large delegation from the Belgian Parliament, because as a follow-up of this initiative by the Council of Ministers, many legislative actions must be taken. I also am delighted that the Minister made a clear commitment to reinforce the Belgian Desk at Eurojust, as foreseen in the new Eurojust Decision.” The Belgian Desk at Eurojust is composed of Ms Michèle Coninsx, Vice-President and National Member for Belgium, and Ms Mieke De Vlaminck, secretary. In addition, eight Belgian nationals work in various occupations as part of the administrative staff of Eurojust. Photos of this visit are available at Eurojust’s Press & PR Service. title: Eurojust coordinates successful arrests in a major cocaine trafficking case
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 6 March 2009 Eurojust, the European Union’s Judicial Cooperation Unit, coordinated the investigations and preparations for prosecutions involving three Member States to resolve a possible conflict of jurisdiction in a major cocaine trafficking case. This week, 32 arrests were made and 100 kg of cocaine were seized by the Italian Carabinieri in Ostia. This was the result of intense cooperation between the Italian, Spanish and French National Members at Eurojust, the Spanish Guardia Civil and French Customs agents, police, investigative judges and prosecutors. A Colombian criminal organisation was trafficking cocaine, via Spain and France, to Italy. At the request of the prosecutor in Rome and the Direzione Antimafia, Eurojust was involved in coordinating, on a European level, the investigations and actions in the three involved Member States. A European Arrest Warrant was issued by the Italian prosecutor towards France, to arrest and extradite three suspects, who were arrested in Lyon and Marseille. BACKGROUNDIn February 2008, a drug courier was arrested, in the area of the jurisdiction of Marseille, while transporting 21 kg of cocaine from Spain via France to Italy. In July 2008, another drug courier was arrested, in the area of the jurisdiction of Lyon, while transporting 10 kg of cocaine from Spain via France to Italy. In Spain, 10 suspects were arrested in October 2008 and 70 kg of cocaine were seized. The Italian investigations uncovered the involvement of the same criminal organisation in all the arrests. Since France is a transit country, it was discovered that the same route was used several times.     Two coordination meetings, in September 2008 and January 2009, took place at Eurojust. During the second meeting, some technical and judicial obstacles were indentified. To avoid a possible conflict of jurisdiction, a solution was reached, as all parties were willing to cooperate in this important case. As the crimes were committed in several Member States, a problem could have arisen due to the ne bis in idem principle, meaning that a person cannot be prosecuted and sentenced twice for the same crimes. Therefore, it was agreed during the meeting at Eurojust that the Spanish and French judicial authorities would transfer the case to the Italian authorities, considered by all the authorities as the country better positioned to prosecute the whole case. The Spanish National Member at Eurojust has also made his recommendation on the best jurisdiction toward the Prosecutor General.  After the successful conclusion of the actions, Mr Filippo Spiezia, Deputy National Member for Italy, commented: “This case confirms that drug trafficking from outside Europe to Member States is still a key issue. This is an important case, showing the necessity of coordination on a European level. Thanks to our meetings in The Hague, we were able to avoid a conflict of jurisdiction, which could have jeopardised the finalisation of the intensive work of all involved parties in these actions.” For more information, please contact: Mr Joannes THUY, Press Officer & SpokespersonEUROJUST, Maanweg 174, 2516 AB, The Hague, The NetherlandsTel +31 70 412 5508 - Fax +31 70 412 5005E-mail: jthuy[AT]eurojust.europa.eu

title: Special Announcement, In Memoriam
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 13 March 2009 IN MEMORIAM António Luís Santos Alves, Deputy National Member for Portugal    On behalf of the Presidency and the Acting Administrative Director of Eurojust, it is our sad duty to inform you that on the morning of 12 March, our colleague, António Luís Santos Alves, Deputy National Member for Portugal, became unwell and sadly passed away. He was surrounded by his colleagues, who provided all possible assistance. António was 47 years old.   António Luís Santos Alves had 20 years’ experience in the Public Prosecution Service. From 2000 to 2002 he was a General Inspector for the Environment and between 2003 and 2004 he was a Counsellor in the Permanent Representation of Portugal to the European Union. António joined Eurojust in April 2004, becoming Deputy National Member for Portugal. Everyone who knew him valued his warmth, his unassuming manner, his sense of honour, and the hard work that he did every day for Eurojust. All Eurojust staff gathered yesterday to pay their respects to their colleague, in the presence of HE Mr Manuel Nuno Tavares de Sousa, Ambassador of Portugal to the Netherlands.In his condolence message, the Acting Administrative Director, Mr Jacques Vos, said: “Words cannot express how sorry we are about this tragic event that has touched us so deeply. I want you all to know that António is in our thoughts and prayers. As we move through the difficult days and weeks ahead, he will be present in our midst. We offer our deepest condolences to his wife and son, his family, relatives and friends.”Ms Michèle Coninsx, Vice-President, paid her respects to António: “It’s hard to be confronted with such a tragic fact of life. António was a warm human being, a good colleague and friend, very committed to his work at Eurojust, generous, and he had his heart in the right place. It’s so unreal and unfair that this warm heart failed him, and left us without him. We will never forget him.” For more information, please contact: Mr Joannes THUY, Press Officer & SpokespersonEUROJUST, Maanweg 174, 2516 AB, The Hague, The NetherlandsTel +31 70 412 5508 - Fax +31 70 412 5005E-mail: jthuy[AT]eurojust.europa.eu

title: UPDATE: Eurojust will be requested to coordinate internet telephony investigations
text: Page Content​NOTE: This is an update of the press release issued on Friday 20 February 2009. Some of the information in this press release was issued prematurely and is therefore incorrect, as there is not yet an official case reported to Eurojust. The Hague, 25 February 2009 At the request of Direzione Nazionale Antimafia in Rome, Ms Carmen Manfredda, acting National Member for Italy at Eurojust, was approached by the Italian judicial authorities with the request to introduce a case to Eurojust. When requested, Eurojust could play an important role in overcoming the technical and legal obstacles to the interception of internet telephony systems, taking into account the various data protection rules and civil rights. In September 2006, a first strategic meeting on internet telephony took place at Eurojust, in the context of another case introduced by Italy. The participants were informed of the technical and legal issues of the subject. Representatives from the company Skype S.A. were invited and present at this meeting. There was a positive message from the Skype representatives during the meeting, showing their commitment to cooperate with the law enforcement authorities in the fight against serious, cross-border organised crime. The participants took into consideration that new VoIP technologies could offer a possible communication channel to criminals and criminal networks. Following a meeting with the judicial authorities in Milan, Italy, Ms Manfredda commented: “The possibility of intercepting internet telephony will be an essential tool in the fight against international organised crime within Europe and beyond. Our aim is not to stop users from taking advantage of internet telephony, but to prevent criminals from using VoIP systems to plan and organise their unlawful actions.” For more information, please contact: Mr Joannes THUY, Press Officer & SpokespersonEUROJUST, Maanweg 174, 2516 AB, The Hague, The NetherlandsTel +31 70 412 5508 - Fax +31 70 412 5005E-mail: jthuy[AT]eurojust.europa.eu

title: Towards closer co-operation between the Public Prosecutors General of the Member States of the European Union
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 14 December 2010 In the framework of the Belgian Presidency of the European Union, the Board of Prosecutors General of Belgium will convene a meeting of the Prosecutors General and Directors of Public Prosecution of all Member States of the European Union. The meeting, organised with the support of Eurojust and the participation of the European Commission and the Secretariat of the Council of the European Union, will take place on 16 December in The Hague. The board of Prosecutors General of Belgium considers that, after a preliminary meeting that took place in Spain (Madrid) in the first half of 2010, the time is ripe to organise the first meeting of the so-called “Consultative Forum of the Prosecutors General and Directors of Public Prosecution”, particularly in light of the new legal framework resulting from the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty on 1 December 2009. The Justice Ministers of the EU Member States had already given an impetus to that initiative at their informal meeting of 15 and 16 July 2010. The participants, including also representatives from Eurojust, will discuss the mandate of the Consultative Forum. The purpose of the Forum, as proposed by the Belgian Presidency, is to encourage the active participation of the judicial authorities of the Member States in the Internal Security Strategy of the EU, thereby strengthening the judicial dimension of the EU policy on fighting against organised crime. In the afternoon, participants will discuss the diverse methodologies applied in the Member States for determining national priorities on criminal policy, and the implications of decisions made at European level on priorities in the field of investigations and prosecutions. The meeting will also create an opportunity for the prosecutors and directors of public action to get to know each other better and to share experiences and best practices in facing common challenges. For more information, please contact:Mr Joannes THUY, Spokesperson - Head of Press & PR ServiceEUROJUST, Maanweg 174, 2516 AB, The Hague, the NetherlandsTel +31 70 412 5508E-mail: jthuy[AT]eurojust.europa.eu

title: Eurojust co-ordinated “Gold Fish” international fraud case
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 20 December 2010 The Italian Desk at Eurojust played an important role in the co-ordination of a huge fraud case in Italy which also involved several European Union Member States. On 17 December, 12 arrest warrants were executed in Naples, Italy, and its surrounding areas by the National Authorities, the Guardia di Finanza and the Carabinieri from Naples. In total, more than 80 police officers were involved in the actions. The case was filed against members of a criminal association engaged in fraud, tax evasion, and false bankruptcy. The criminal organisation began operating in 2005 using a network of six (fake) commercial companies. The operation was called “Gold Fish”, due to the type of fraud involved. The criminal organisation bought large quantities of sea fish from companies located abroad, mainly in the North of Europe, such as Norway and Denmark, but also in Greece, France, Spain, and Portugal. They used fake companies as buyers, portraying themselves as reliable companies using sophisticated computer tools to publish false information on the Internet, provided false social security documents and information to the competent social administrations, and used false money bills of exchange. The financial damage and losses for the victims and national authorities was immense and alarming: 3 million euro for the private sector, 28 million euro VAT tax evasion and 25 million euro involving false bankruptcy. In Italy, Eurojust’s assistance and its role in the case has been highlighted by the Italian preliminary judge as a crucial in co-ordinating the execution of several requests for judicial assistance in Greece, France, Spain, Portugal, Norway and Denmark. Afterwards, Mr Filippo Spiezia, Deputy National Member for Italy at Eurojust, commented: “This was an important case and the Italian authorities enjoyed great success thanks to the support and co-ordination of Eurojust. This morning’s arrests confirmed the powerful effects of financial fraud, ranging from reduced economic activity and tax losses. The actions of this criminal network are detrimental to Italy, especially in these difficult economic times.” For more information, please contact:Mr Joannes THUY, Spokesperson - Head of Press & PR ServiceEUROJUST, Maanweg 174, 2516 AB, The Hague, the NetherlandsTel +31 70 412 5508E-mail: jthuy[AT]eurojust.europa.eu

title: Mr Raivo Sepp re-elected as Vice-President
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 27 October 2010 Mr Raivo Sepp, National Member for Estonia, was re-elected today as Vice-President of Eurojust for a second 3-year term starting on 9 November 2010. Yesterday, during a special plenary meeting, the College of Eurojust re-elected Raivo Sepp, National Member for Estonia, as their Vice-President. This election must be approved by the Council of the European Union by qualified majority. On 13 September 2007, Mr Raivo Sepp was first elected as Vice-President for Eurojust. The election today was due to the end of the mandate of Mr Sepp, on 9 November 2010, after completing his first 3-year term. Together with Mr Aled Williams, the National Member for the United Kingdom and President, and Ms Michèle Coninsx, the National Member for Belgium and Vice-President, Mr Sepp will represent the College, substitute for the President in his absence, assist with management of the College and monitor the daily work of Eurojust’s Administrative Director. Raivo Sepp joined Eurojust in May 2004. He has 21 years' experience in the judiciary. He started his career in the prosecution service as an investigator. He has also worked as the Director of the Pre-trial Investigation Bureau. Later, he was the County Police Chief and the Deputy Director General of the Police Board. He served for five years as the Prosecutor General of the Republic. During his first mandate as Vice-President, Mr Sepp was involved in the ongoing Organisational Structure Review. This is one of the most important projects for Eurojust’s future development and for the improvement of its efficiency and image. Mr Sepp was also actively involved in the preparation and drafting of the Multi-annual Strategic Plan (MASP) and the Annual Work Programmes of Eurojust for 2010 and 2011. He was Chair of a task force, recently created to facilitate a clear presentation of Eurojust’s statistical data to stakeholders of Eurojust. He was also involved in the strategic project for improving the working methods and amending the Rules of Procedure of the College. After the election, Mr Williams, President of Eurojust, commented: “Raivo's re-election as Vice-President of Eurojust is an important mandate from the Eurojust College. In our rapidly developing judicial co-operation unit, and following the Treaty of Lisbon and revised Eurojust Decision, much work lies ahead and it will be important to have strong and experienced colleagues in the Presidency Team.” Ms Coninsx, Vice-President of Eurojust, said: “The re-election of my colleague is the recognition of his hard work, commitment to Eurojust and expertise in management at Eurojust. He is a loyal and correct team player and I really look forward to continuing to work with him in the Presidency Team.” Mr Sepp commented: “I am delighted and it is an honour to be re-elected as Vice-President of such an important organisation. I have been the National Member for Estonia at Eurojust for more than six years. During that time I have often assisted my national authorities by facilitating and co-ordinating criminal investigations and prosecutions. My re-election as Vice-President is a vote of confidence from the College and a recognition of my significant contribution to the work of Eurojust from different posts of responsibility. This work has allowed me to be involved in many initiatives and to have gained experience and a unique perspective on the work of Eurojust.” For more information, please contact:Mr Joannes THUY, Spokesperson - Head of Press & PR ServiceEUROJUST, Maanweg 174, 2516 AB, The Hague, the NetherlandsTel +31 70 412 5508E-mail: jthuy[AT]eurojust.europa.eu

title: Major action against criminal organisation “Enfants des Métros”
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 2 December 2010 On 30 November, a large-scale police and judicial action was simultaneously executed in France and Italy against an international gang called “Children of the Metros.” The actions were co-ordinated by Eurojust. Early in the morning, police forces in France and Italy took co-ordinated action against a criminal organisation operating in the Metros of Paris and Rome. The criminal organisation used children between the ages of 10 and 16 to steal wallets and purses in the Metros. The victims were primarily tourists. Young accomplices aged 17 to 19 organised the thefts on the spot. French police forces arrested 16 suspects, and the Italian police forces arrested 6 suspects. The criminal organisation is also suspected of organising money-laundering and illegal car trafficking schemes. On 27 October, a co-ordination meeting involving all parties took place at Eurojust’s headquarters in The Hague. A French Investigating Magistrate issued European Arrest Warrants following the meeting. After the arrests, Mr Gérard Loubens, National Member for France at Eurojust, commented: “These arrests provide yet another example of the added value of Eurojust in co-ordinating large-scale police and judicial actions. Eurojust provided the opportunity for the competent authorities to get together and plan their strategy, leading to this very successful outcome.” For more information, please contact:Mr Joannes THUY, Spokesperson - Head of Press & PR ServiceEUROJUST, Maanweg 174, 2516 AB, The Hague, the NetherlandsTel +31 70 412 5508E-mail: jthuy[AT]eurojust.europa.eu

title: Eurojust received EU grant to support Joint Investigation Teams
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 1 October 2010 Eurojust further promotes the use of Joint Investigation Teams with a European Commission grant. The second JIT Funding Project is ready to launch. Background:A Joint Investigation Team (JIT) is an investigation team set up on the basis of an agreement between two or more Member States and/or other parties, for a specific purpose and a limited duration. Exchange of information can be immediate. JIT members can be present at house searches, interviews, etc. in all jurisdictions covered, helping to overcome language barriers. JITs allow Europol and Eurojust to be involved by providing direct support and assistance, and EU funding is possible. Based on its successful application under the European Commission’s Specific Programme “Prevention of and Fight against Crime 2009”, Eurojust was awarded a new grant of € 2 159 160 for an action entitled “Supporting Greater Usage of Joint Investigation Teams”. The awarded funds, which represent 95% of the total amount available for this project, will be used to provide financial and logistical support to JITs through the second Eurojust JIT Funding Project. This new project, which is the continuation of the pilot JIT Funding Project, is ready to be launched and will end in September 2013. Eurojust will continue to award grants for the financing of JITs for two common types of expenses incurred by the parties involved in fighting cross-border crime: travel and accommodation costs, and translation and interpretation costs. A supply of office equipment kits, consisting of mobile phones, laptops, mobile scanners and printers, is also available to be lent to JIT members to ensure good communication and information exchange for JITs throughout the Member States. Eurojust’s goal, via this project, is to support the creation of new JITs to fight cross-border crime and also to support JITs already in existence by improving their access to possible financial assistance. Eurojust believes that such support will have a positive practical impact on the fight against cross-border crime. Eurojust will continue to establish itself as a centre of expertise for JITs, providing guidance, support and assistance. Further information is available at:JITs Funding Project. For more information, please contact:Mr Joannes THUY, Spokesperson - Head of Press & PR ServiceEUROJUST, Maanweg 174, 2516 AB, The Hague, the NetherlandsTel +31 70 412 5508E-mail: jthuy[AT]eurojust.europa.eu

title: Meeting of the Consultative Forum of the Prosecutors General and Directors of Public Prosecutions of the Member States
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 17 December 2010 At the initiative of the Board of Prosecutors General of Belgium, and in the framework of the Belgian Presidency of the European Union, the Prosecutors General and Directors of Public Prosecutions of the Member States of the EU held a meeting in The Hague on 16 December 2010 , with the co-operation and support of Eurojust. The ‘Consultative Forum of the Prosecutors General and Directors of Public Prosecutions’ met again, after its first gathering under the Spanish Presidency, and agreed on its mandate. The Consultative Forum is based upon, inter alia, the following principles: It shall assemble representatives from all Member States who hold the highest level positions within public prosecution systems; It shall meet at least once a year, at the invitation of the Member State holding the EU Presidency; and Eurojust shall be asked to host meetings of the Consultative Forum at its premises in The Hague. The Consultative Forum has affirmed its main objective to promote the strengthening of the judicial dimension of the EU’s internal security by: Based on their practical judicial experience, discussing the trends of criminality impacting the EU which could result in an input provided to Eurojust; Discussing, with a view to improving international judicial and police cooperation and contributing to a EU vision and sharing experiences of prosecution strategies and best practices: In the main areas of serious and organised crime (such as trafficking in human beings, drug trafficking, terrorism, fraud, and other offences affecting the financial interests of the EU), In the use of procedures, particularly investigative techniques and rules of evidence, and In the use of practical cooperation measures, particularly the European Arrest Warrant and international letters rogatory; Contributing to the evaluation of lessons learned, in view of their integration into the next policy cycle; Based on their practical judicial experience, when appropriate, contributing to legislative initiatives taken at EU level. The incoming Hungarian and Polish Presidencies have already announced their intention to convene meetings of the Consultative Forum in 2011. For more information, please contact:Mr Joannes THUY, Spokesperson - Head of Press & PR ServiceEUROJUST, Maanweg 174, 2516 AB, The Hague, the NetherlandsTel +31 70 412 5508E-mail: jthuy[AT]eurojust.europa.eu

title: “Lost Boy”: Eurojust facilitates dismantling of a worldwide child abuse network
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 15 December 2010 In 2008, Eurojust, the European Union’s Judicial Co-operation Unit, registered a case codenamed “Lost Boy”. The case was registered at the request of the Norwegian Liaison Prosecutor, to support an investigation into the sexual abuse of minors and the production and distribution of child abuse images. As the investigation developed, it revealed possible links to other countries and suspects, including Italy, the United States of America, Romania, the United Kingdom, Belgium, France, Germany, the Netherlands, the Czech Republic, Afghanistan and Brazil. As a result of the efforts of the national authorities of the countries involved, which were co-ordinated from Eurojust, a worldwide paedophile network was uncovered, offenders were identified and arrested and numerous victims were rescued. The users of the network, some of whom were actually engaged in sexual molestation of children, resided in Europe, North and South America and New Zealand and victims were to be found worldwide. The US network operated as a forum for the production and distribution of child abuse materials. Some of the offenders met personally and exchanged child abuse materials, or made trips together. Internet was widely used to communicate and exchange materials. An online message board was especially created for the purpose. It was based on sophisticated security protocols and brought together technologically advanced users communicating via public posts and private messages. The users of the board, some of whom were actually engaged in sexual molestation of children, resided in Europe, North and South America and New Zealand and victims were to be found worldwide. As a result of the targeted and efficient law enforcement and judicial efforts over the last couple of years, investigations were launched and progressed and arrests of offenders took place. Forensic examination of seized computers helped discover multiple terabytes of incriminating materials, including millions of child abuse images and thousands of videos, and provided evidence and links between offenders in different countries. Victims of sexual abuse were identified in Norway, Romania, Brazil and other countries. Some of the evidence seized by the national authorities proved vital for investigations and judicial proceedings in other countries. So far, about 30 suspects are under investigation; more than 70 victims were identified. Eurojust facilitated successfully the co-operation and co-ordination among judicial and law enforcement authorities of the involved countries. Five co-ordination meetings were held during which the participating countries shared evidence and co-ordinated requests for mutual legal assistance and actions against the criminal network. The co-ordination and exchange of information via Eurojust facilitated the initiation and conduct of investigations in some of the involved countries. Issues regarding the competent jurisdiction to investigate and prosecute were solved. Joint actions by the Norwegian, Italian, Romanian and US authorities were planned and executed, including house searches, arrests and hearing of suspects. Ms Anne Grøstad, the Norwegian Liaison Prosecutor to Eurojust, commented on the results: “This case is a very good example of speed, commitment and co-ordination in international judicial co-operation. The involvement of Eurojust has been crucial for the disclosure of a worldwide paedophile criminal network and the rescue of innocent victims. In Norway, the law enforcement and judicial efforts resulted in a District Court ruling in January 2010 convicting an offender to 10 years of preventive detention and ordering compensation for victims. The conviction was confirmed by the Appeal Court in October and a decision of the Supreme Court on the case is currently pending. The presence of Romanian victims who testified at the trial in Norway was of a particular importance for the successful outcome.” Ms Mary Lee Warren, Liaison Prosecutor for the United States at Eurojust, added: “The excellent international co-operation with Eurojust and the other European Member States made it possible for the USA to investigate the case in our own backyard. We will be able to further investigate and prosecute the criminals in an effective way and rescue the children.” For more information, please contact:Mr Joannes THUY, Spokesperson - Head of Press & PR ServiceEUROJUST, Maanweg 174, 2516 AB, The Hague, the NetherlandsTel +31 70 412 5508E-mail: jthuy[AT]eurojust.europa.eu

title: Mr Jesper Hjortenberg appointed as new National Member for Denmark at Eurojust
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 05 October 2010 On 1 September 2010, Mr Jesper Hjortenberg was appointed as National Member for Denmark at Eurojust. In accordance with Article 9(3) of the Eurojust Decision, the appointment must be approved by the Secretary General of the European Council to become effective. The former National Member for Denmark, Mr Lennart Lindblom, has returned to Copenhagen to work as a Deputy Director of Public Prosecutions. Mr Hjortenberg has been a prosecutor since 1988, and has worked at the Office of the Danish Director of Public Prosecutions for many years. From 2002 to 2007, he was Head of the International Division of the DPP’s Office, and since 2007, served as Deputy Director with responsibilities for casework and international matters. He prosecuted a large number of cases before the Danish Supreme Court from 1996 to 2010. Mr Hjortenberg negotiated the EU 2000 Convention on mutual legal assistance and the 2002 Eurojust Decision as part of the Danish delegation at the meetings in Brussels and has been Danish member of the Council of Europe Steering Committee on Crime Problems (CDPC) for more than ten years. He is currently a member of the CDPC Bureau. Mr Hjortenberg commented: “My appointment as National Member for Denmark at Eurojust seems a natural step in my career, following my involvement in the drafting of the Eurojust Decision in 2002 and my participation in international judicial co-operation. I already know many of the National Members. It is no real surprise that I ended up here. I find the work environment very challenging and interesting.”     Mr Jesper Hjortenberg(photo in hi-res available from Eurojust) For more information, please contact:Mr Joannes THUY, Spokesperson - Head of Press & PR ServiceEUROJUST, Maanweg 174, 2516 AB, The Hague, the NetherlandsTel +31 70 412 5508E-mail: jthuy[AT]eurojust.europa.eu

title: 6th Expert meeting on Joint Investigation Teams
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 3 December 2010 Experts from EU Member States met on 2 and 3 December in The Hague to discuss and share knowledge on Joint Investigation Teams (JITs). The conference was jointly organised by Europol and Eurojust and hosted representatives from the EU Council Secretariat, European Commission, Frontex, OLAF, and the LIBE Committee of the European Parliament. Participants focused on the exchange of best practices for running a JIT, JIT funding opportunities, profile requirements for successful JIT experts at national level, and how to further stimulate the use of the Joint Investigation Team tool. A JIT is a time-limited investigation team set up between two or more EU countries (and/or third parties) to fight serious cross-border crime. In particular, a JIT is appropriate for a demanding or difficult investigation requiring special co-ordination or concerted actions. At the meeting, EU Member States were encouraged to adopt an integrated approach to JITs, involving national prosecutors and investigators together with representatives from Eurojust and Europol. This approach will ensure that Europol is in a position to assist with its analysis of criminal intelligence and Eurojust with co-ordination of judicial actions. In recent years, Europol and Eurojust have supported several Joint Investigation Teams fighting organised crime activities such as drug trafficking, trafficking in human beings and euro counterfeiting. A JIT manual, to guide practitioners through setting up a JIT, has been produced and is available in 22 EU languages on the websites of Europol and Eurojust (https://www.europol.europa.eu/content/page/jit-manual-995) AND (http://www.eurojust.europa.eu/jit.htm). Europol and Eurojust officials can assist by supporting the activities of, and information exchange with, members of the Joint Investigation Team. Europol can also offer operational support by deploying the mobile office, to provide quick analytical feedback of criminal intelligence, as well as providing forensic expertise. Eurojust can also help with the drafting of JIT agreements and financial support of JITs. The advantages of using a Joint Investigation Team are: information can be shared directly among JIT members without the need for formal requests; team members can request investigative measures or coercive measures from other team members directly, dispensing with the need for Letters Rogatory; JIT members can be present at house searches, interviews, in all jurisdictions covered, helping to overcome language barriers in interviews, etc; efforts can be co-ordinated on the spot and specialised knowledge can be informally exchanged; mutual trust is built between practitioners from different jurisdictions working together and deciding on investigative and prosecution strategies; Europol and Eurojust can be involved with direct support and assistance; and JITs may also secure potentially available funding. The legal basis for JITs is mainly set out in the 2000 EU Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters, and Council Decisions on Europol and Eurojust. A JIT Secretariat will be established at Eurojust early next year. For more information, please contact:Mr Joannes THUY, Spokesperson - Head of Press & PR ServiceEUROJUST, Maanweg 174, 2516 AB, The Hague, the NetherlandsTel +31 70 412 5508E-mail: jthuy[AT]eurojust.europa.eu

title: 9th Genocide Network meeting: 9th Genocide Network meeting
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 26 October 2010 On 14 and 15 October, the 9th meeting of the European Union Network of Contact Points in respect of persons responsible for genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity was held at Eurojust. The meeting, organised by the Belgian Presidency of the EU and supported by Eurojust, was attended by delegations from 16 Member States, as well as representatives from Norway, Switzerland and the USA, the European Commission, the General Secretariat of the Council, the ICTY, ICTR, the International Criminal Court, the International Committee of the Red Cross, Redress-FIDH, the Coalition for an International Criminal Court, Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International. Mr Gérard Dive, representing the Belgian Presidency, chaired the meeting. The agenda of the 9th meeting included a number of issues agreed by the Trio Presidency as important issues to be followed in the course of the current Trio Presidency. The development of an 18-month work programme was suggested to be developed at the network’s 7th meeting in December 2009. One of the main topics of this 9th meeting was the protection of witnesses and practical issues in relation to the identification and hearing of witnesses. In addition, the participants discussed the international framework for international legal co-operation, the application of extraterritorial jurisdiction by States and current developments at the ICTY, the ICTR and the ICC. The participants also touched upon several organisational issues, including the establishment of a Secretariat of the network in early 2011, which, in accordance with the new Eurojust Decision of December 2008, will be established within Eurojust to further improve and co-ordinate co-operation within the Network. The next meeting of the network, under the Hungarian Presidency, is scheduled to take place during the first half of 2011. BACKGROUNDThe Genocide Network was established in 2002 by the Council to improve co-operation between the EU Member States in relation to the prosecution of genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity. During network meetings, contact points regularly exchange information related to cases pending within their jurisdiction and other practical information to improve co-operation with each other and third parties. title: Strategic seminar - A European Public Prosecutor's Office from Eurojust?
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 29 September 2010 Presidency of the Council of the European Union, held a strategic seminar, "Eurojust and the Lisbon Treaty: towards more effective action". The seminar was hosted by the College of Europe in Bruges, Belgium. The goals of the seminar were to reflect on the further development of Eurojust under the Lisbon Treaty, particularly the regulation for Eurojust under Article 85, and the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office from Eurojust under Article 86. The seminar was attended by both academics and practitioners, including representatives from all EU Member States, the Council, the Commission, the LIBE Committee Secretariat of the European Parliament, the European Court of Justice, the Conférence des organes spécialisés dans les affaires communautaires (COSAC) Secretariat, OLAF and Europol. Opening speeches were given by Mr Paul Demaret, Rector of the College of Europe, HE Mr Stefaan De Clerck, Justice Minister of Belgium, Mr Johan Delmulle, Federal Prosecutor of Belgium, Ms Françoise Le Bail, Director General, DG Justice, European Commission, Mr Aled Williams, President of Eurojust and Ms Michèle Coninsx, Vice-President of Eurojust. Mr Demaret underlined the European spirit and dimension of the College of Europe and thanked Eurojust for the choice of the College as the location of the seminar. The Lisbon Treaty envisages both change and continuity for Eurojust. The President of Eurojust considers that the recognition of the continuing value of Eurojust and the proposals for change through redefinition of its powers and tasks is not controversial, but is still an important starting point. “Co-ordination occupies a central role in Eurojust's casework”, Mr Williams said. Co-ordination meetings with national investigating and prosecuting authorities show an increase similar to that of casework generally. In 2009, Eurojust held 131 co-ordination meetings with authorities from the Member States and other EU bodies. The Lisbon Treaty envisages a greater role for Eurojust in cross-border investigations and prosecutions, but in partnership with national authorities. The Minister of Justice stressed that Belgium is a strong defender of Eurojust and that Eurojust should receive all the possible support to continue working. “The Lisbon Treaty means further work on judicial issues: criminality has become international, so international co-operation is essential. The Belgian Presidency will focus on the improvement of judicial co-operation between Member States. There is a need for more efficient legal instruments to enhance co-operation, for example, the proposal on the EU investigation warrant for evidence collection abroad.” Minister De Clerck also elaborated on the achievements of Eurojust. "Eurojust already came a long way. I am a believer, and I am sure there will be a consensus found between the EU’s Member States in the establishment of the Office of the European Public Prosecutor from Eurojust. The new Eurojust Decision has not yet been transposed in Belgian law. However, a legal initiative is in preparation with the involvement of the Federal Prosecutor’s Office. This involvement was highly recommended by Federal Prosecutor Delmulle, a practitioner, who is convinced that the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, which at all times keeps in touch with the competent judicial authorities of the Member States, will be of the utmost importance. Ms Le Bail, the Director-General for Justice, represented Vice-President and Commissioner Ms Viviane Reding. The Commission envisages several achievements in the near future, especially in the criminal justice area. “Better judicial co-operation is needed”, she said, “and we have now an opportunity we must not let go.” Eurojust is in the process of strengthening its powers and a possible reform, and the same is happening to OLAF, the European Union’s Anti-Fraud Office. Ms Le Bail repeated Ms Reding’s pledge to put forward a proposal to establish the European Public Prosecutors Office during her mandate. In her speech, Ms Coninsx said, “Eurojust is now focusing on key issues, and both the College and the administration devote most of their time and efforts to the reorganisation of Eurojust's internal structure to make it more efficient and more oriented to the support of its core business, and the improvement of the operational work of the National Members and the College, in close co-operation with the national authorities of the Member States, and in line with the priorities identified by the Council in the fight against serious organised crime.” Eurojust is committed to improving its expertise in the protection of the financial interests of the EU. Also in this particular field, Eurojust needs the information from the national authorities of the Member States and from Europol. The participants elaborated on the various topics, such as the structure and institutional development of Eurojust, the operational powers of Eurojust, the exchange of information with Member States and operational co-operation with Europol, OLAF and third States, the resolution of conflicts of jurisdiction, the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office and its relationship with Eurojust, competences and rules of procedure, the admissibility of evidence and judicial review. In the general conclusions future perspectives were highlighted by Mr Daniel Flore, General Counsellor, Ministry of Justice of Belgium. Some questions still remain unanswered; some are very complex but the different options put forward and discussed in the workshops give us a basis for further elaborations on the matter and will enable the European Commission and other key players to go deeper into the issues. After the seminar, a debate with students of the College of Europe took place, led by Prof Jörg Monar of the College of Europe, and with panelists Prof Henri Labayle, University of Pau, Prof Gert Vermeulen, University of Ghent, Mr Thomas Lamiroy, National Correspondent for Eurojust, and Ms Coninsx. After the seminar, Vice-President Coninsx commented: “We are very grateful for the active input from all the participants, and the fruitful discussions arising from the high quality of the contributions. There are still many unanswered questions on the future of Eurojust and the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office from Eurojust. Thanks to the support of Minister De Clerck and the Belgian Presidency, we had the opportunity to reflect on the future development of Eurojust. Now, all of us at Eurojust need to streamline our vision using all the input we received during the seminar and provide solid contributions to the European Commission and the Council of the European Union on how, on the basis of Eurojust’s experience, we envisage the development of Eurojust role in co-ordinating judicial co-operation between the investigating and prosecuting authorities of the Member States as described in article 85 of the Lisbon Treaty and how the Office of the European Public Prosecutor could be established from Eurojust.” See also: Belgian presidency in push for EU prosecutor's office, EU Observer For more information, please contact:Mr Joannes THUY, Spokesperson - Head of Press & PR ServiceEUROJUST, Maanweg 174, 2516 AB, The Hague, the NetherlandsTel +31 70 412 5508E-mail: jthuy[AT]eurojust.europa.eu

title: Eurojust visit to CEPOL Secretariat
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 26 July 2010 Aled Williams, President of Eurojust, and Andrew Crookes, Eurojust UK Deputy National Member and contact point for CEPOL, visited the CEPOL Secretariat on 19 July. During their visit, they met with Dr Ferenc Bánfi, CEPOL Director, and Detlef Schröder, Head of Programmes. The Eurojust representatives heard about CEPOL’s new strategic approach and discussed future co-operation possibilities between the two EU agencies, following the Memorandum of Understanding signed last year. Mr Williams said: “For Eurojust, CEPOL is an important co-operating agency in the Justice and Home Affairs area. In recent years we have already implemented good operational co-operation in the training area. I also see good opportunities for further co-operation at a strategic level.” Mr Schröder added: “We discussed the possibility to enhance co-operation between CEPOL and Eurojust, identifying specific possibilities for future collaboration in the areas of our courses and seminars and for the elaboration of common multi-professional training initiatives.” left to right: Messrs Detlef Schröder, Ferenc Bánfi, Aled Williams and Andrew Crookes BACKGROUNDEurojust is a judicial cooperation body created to help provide safety within an area of freedom, security and justice. Set up by the Council of the European Union in February 2002 to improve the fight against serious crime by facilitating the optimal co-ordination of action for investigations and prosecutions covering the territory of more than one Member State with full respect for fundamental rights and freedoms, Eurojust is composed of 27 National Members, one from each EU Member State. These are senior and experienced judges, prosecutors, or police officers of equivalent competence, who together form the College of Eurojust. title: Strategic Seminar - Establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office from Eurojust?
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 8 September 2010 On 21 and 22 September 2010, Eurojust, in co-operation with the Belgian Presidency of the Council of the European Union, will hold a strategic seminar, "Eurojust and the Lisbon Treaty: towards more effective action". title: Eurojust co-ordinated action against computer piracy in 13 countries
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 8 September 2010 On 07 September, a large Europe-wide co-ordinated police and judicial action took place in 13 countries against groups of computer servers hosting pirated material and networks disseminating it. The Computer Crime Unit (FCCU) of the Belgian Federal Police and the Investigating Judge Wim De Troy of Brussels launched this international operation to stop the activities of groups of users and providers in illegally copying and distributing films and TV series. Since the start of the investigation two years ago, the four most prominent groups involved in the distribution on the internet of 80% of the productions in the Dutch language or foreign languages with Dutch subtitles have been identified. The Investigating Judge and the FCCU involved Eurojust and Europol in The Hague to co-ordinate the international actions. On 07 July 2010, the Belgian Desk at Eurojust asked the National Members from the Member States involved, and the Liaison Magistrates of Croatia and Norway based in Eurojust, to transmit letters of request and to facilitate their execution in their countries. The international co-ordinated action, to close down and seize 48 servers or groups of servers identified as part of the network hosting pirated material, took place in 13 countries: Belgium, the Netherlands, United Kingdom, France, Poland, Sweden, Austria, Czech Republic, Germany, Hungary, Italy, Norway, and Croatia. A total of 16 persons have been arrested so far. It was estimated that the pirated material represents a loss of authors’ rights and income for production companies of € 30 million in Belgium alone and up to € 6 billion in Europe. After the action, the Belgian Investigating Judge commented: “This action could not be accomplished in such a successful way without the co-operation of Eurojust.” Mr Daniel Bernard, Seconded National Expert for Belgium at Eurojust, said: “Once again Eurojust proved its unique position in the European Union’s area of Freedom, Security and Justice. We were able to co-ordinate in a very short time synchronised judicial actions within 13 countries via the involvement of the National Desks and Liaison Magistrates at Eurojust.” BACKGROUND The action took place against users and providers hosting networks of illegal file-sharing of copyrighted works utilising a so-called “rip box”, a high-powered computer that can quickly decode and transform film and video into the appropriate format. It is believed that the network providers were unwittingly used by the international criminal networks in the furtherance of these offences in making a large amount of movies and TV shows available on the internet. title: Large network of Albanian-speaking criminals dismantled with the support of Europol and Eurojust
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 17 August 2010 After more than a year of investigations in Belgium, France, Germany, Italy and the Netherlands, a significant criminal network - of nearly 100 individuals - has been dismantled, composed mainly of Albanian-speaking criminals involved in cocaine trafficking. Five operations were brought to successful conclusions following extensive cooperation between international judicial and police authorities, supported by Europol and Eurojust. Eurojust organised the first coordination meeting back in 2009 and continued acting as the platform for judicial cooperation, facilitating all activities among the prosecuting authorities in the affected countries, up to the point of execution of the latest European Arrest Warrants (EAWs). Europol facilitated the organisation of operational meetings at Europol in 2009, as well as coordinating a number of police operations, collecting large quantities of data and intelligence, and supporting the relevant investigative teams in the Member States with numerous intelligence reports. In a number of cases the positive identification of key suspects was based upon Europol intelligence. The investigation was initiated by the Carabinieri of Ferrara and alone in Italy the international police cooperation led to the identification and referral of 76 suspects to the local judicial authorities. 40 of these were arrested while the remaining suspects are still at large. In addition, a number of key Albanian criminals were caught in Belgium, Germany and Italy in connection with cocaine trafficking. Additionally, 6 kg heroin, 2.5 kg cocaine and various cutting substances, packing materials and equipment were seized during the operation. In France, 22 Albanian-speaking suspects were arrested, 3.2 kg of heroin were seized, as well as €127 000 in cash. Mutual legal assistance requests, issued by the French judicial authorities, are being executed in several countries. The investigation in Belgium led to the arrest of 3 people and the seizure of 30 kg of cannabis, cutting agents, packing materials and packing equipment. The Dutch investigation led to the confiscation of 20 kg of cannabis and seizure of firearms and weaponry, while in Germany 7 people were investigated. The highly successful outcome of these coordinated investigations underlines the effectiveness of international judicial and police cooperation in the European Union, and serves as an example of the value in using Europol and Eurojust to support cross-border investigations into serious and organised crime in Member States. title: Eurojust Annual Report 2009 available online
text: Page ContentThe Hague, 21 July 2010 The Eurojust Annual Report 2009 is now available on the Eurojust website. Following a Council recommendation, the report focuses on Eurojust’s operational work in light of the EU priorities: terrorism, drug trafficking, trafficking in human beings, fraud, corruption, cybercrime, money laundering, and other activities related to the presence of organised crime groups in the economy. Each priority crime area is considered from the perspective of judicial co-ordination and co-operation, and includes information on obstacles, problems, best practice, and solutions found in judicial co-operation. The new approach is designed to make the report more accessible and useful to practitioners. 18 case examples illustrate in concrete terms the added value of Eurojust. Continuing the trend of previous years, the number of cases referred to Eurojust by Member States in 2009 continued to increase. 1 372 cases were referred, which was 15 per cent more than in 2008. Eurojust held 131 co-ordination meetings, where investigators and prosecutors met to ensure the efficient use of Member States’ resources in cross-border crime cases. 2009 also saw progress in the implementation of the new Council Decision on the strengthening of Eurojust. The Decision enables Eurojust to play a more effective role in assisting national authorities when dealing with serious cross-border crime. Eurojust also prepared to meet the new challenges of the Lisbon Treaty and the Stockholm Programme. Council Conclusions on the Eurojust Annual Report 2009 welcome the new report format, based on improved case evaluation tools and procedures. Versions of the Annual Report 2009 in all official languages of the EU will be published on the Eurojust website in the near future. For a downloadable copy in English or one of the other languages currently available, please consult this link: http://www.eurojust.europa.eu/doclibrary/corporate/Pages/annual-reports.aspx. title: Strategic seminar on Eurojust and the Lisbon Treaty
